title: February Thaw at the Flea Market
description: Dear Diary:

title: Twitter Fails E.U. Standard on Removing Hate Speech Online
description: Twitter has failed to meet European standards for removing hate speech online, figures to be published Thursday show, as pressure mounts, particularly on the Continent, for tech companies to do more to tackle such harmful material.

title: Obamas Pay $8.1 Million for Home Just Miles From White House
description: WASHINGTON  President Barack Obama and his wife, Michelle, who have spent the past few months slowly figuring out the rhythm of post-White House life, have taken some time to invest in local real estate: They just spent $8.1 million to buy the mansion theyve been renting in an exclusive neighborhood here.

title: Review: The Incomparable Rose Hartman Snaps Glimpses of the Glitterati
description: Pushy, judgmental, tart-tongued and self-obsessed, the photographer at the heart of Otis Masss penetrating documentary, The Incomparable Rose Hartman, is, like her snapshots, a piece of work. Ms. Hartman made her name documenting the Studio 54 scene in the 1970s. (Her most famous image may be of Bianca Jagger at the nightclub, astride a horse.) Today she remains a tireless fixture of Manhattan night life, flitting about in her tinted glasses, cropped blond hairdo and high-end designer plumage, attending openings, parties and fashion events, in pursuit of revealing glimpses of the glitterati. And Ms. Hartman indisputably has a gift for capturing the spontaneous moment.

title: City Law Illegally Promotes Unionization of Carwash Workers, Judge Rules
description: A federal judge ruled on Wednesday that a city law to regulate carwash businesses violated federal law because it encouraged unionization, dealing a blow to Mayor Bill de Blasios efforts to increase protections for low-wage carwash employees.

title: Review: In Dean, Demetri Martin Doodles Through Grief
description: Demetri Martin joins the ranks of comics who have written and directed films with the movie Dean, a mild but respectable story about a father and son who react to grief differently and have to recalibrate their relationship as a result.

title: Yankees Slugger Aaron Judge Is Third in Early All-Star Voting
description: BALTIMORE  Before a recent Yankees game against the Tampa Bay Rays, Aaron Judge was stopped by a security guard as he was entering the visitors clubhouse at Tropicana Field.

title: Comey Expected to Testify Before Senate, if He Isnt Blocked
description: Senators expect the former F.B.I. director, James B. Comey, to testify next week about his conversations with President Trump, congressional officials said on Wednesday, setting up a test of the White Houses willingness to cooperate with investigations into Mr. Trumps associates.

title: Sorry, Cavaliers. Its Warriors (in Four, Five, Six or Seven).
description: For the third time in three years, the Golden State Warriors and the Cleveland Cavaliers will go at it in the N.B.A. finals, which begin Thursday night. We asked more than a dozen writers and editors at The New York Times for their take on the series. While most of them picked the Warriors, there were dissenters, too. Their thoughts:

title: Review: Radio Dreams Builds a Spiritual Home for Stateless Souls
description: The fictional San Francisco radio station PARS-FM, where much of Radio Dreams is set, is a study in gray and yellow. Its broadcasting booth is illuminated by a single glowing bulb, and its walls are covered in egg-carton-like soundproofing baffles. Multiple clocks on a wall giving times for cities from around the world are the only decorative feature of an adjacent conference room. If an Iranian in Tokyo is listening and its 4 a.m. there, you know then to say good morning, explains the station manager, Hamid, a grave fellow with a wild mane of white hair. Cozy it is not, yet this Farsi-language station is a spiritual home for Hamid and the stateless musicians and business people who move in and out of the place during the course of a day.

title: The Back Story on Trump and Medicaid
description: What can history tell us about the potential impact of President Trump's drastic cuts to Medicaid?

title: Trump Considers Rolling Back Obamas Opening With Cuba
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump is considering reversing major pieces of the Obama administrations opening with Cuba and reinstating limits on travel and commerce, citing human rights abuses by the Castro government as justification for a more punitive approach.

title: Review: In Letters From Baghdad, a Woman Who Trod the Sands of History
description: Letters From Baghdad: The True Story of Gertrude Bell and Iraq, directed by Sabine Krayenbhl and Zeva Oelbaum, is an experiment in documentary form  an unfortunate choice that perhaps looked good on paper. Bell was born into a wealthy British family in 1868, and was an avid traveler from an early age. This movie focuses on her time in the Middle East during the early 20th century and her role in drawing the modern borders of Iraq, which the United States and other countries have expended a good deal of blood and treasure to maintain and defend.

title: Less Tweeting, Lawyers Beg. Covfefe, the President Says.
description: WASHINGTON  There was a time in the not-too-distant past when President Trump refrained from flamethrowing messages on Twitter.

title: White House Details Ethics Waivers for Ex-Lobbyists and Corporate Lawyers
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has given at least 16 White House staff members dispensation to work on policy matters they handled while employed as lobbyists or to interact with their former colleagues in private-sector jobs, according to records released late Wednesday.

title: Income Swings Are Largest Among the Poor and the Rich
description: Monthly swings in income can vary widely depending on how much you make

title: Steady Jobs, With Pay and Hours That Are Anything But
description: Mirella Casares has what used to be considered the keystone of economic security: a job. But even a reliable paycheck no longer delivers a reliable income.

title: Quotation of the Day: Steady Paycheck, Shaky Income, Rising Angst
description: Were given three bras and a bottle of Bombshell, their No. 1 selling perfume.

title: Cowboys May Ride Off Into It
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Todays puzzle might not go down well with proponents of flat Earth theories or those who might believe that the sun revolves around the Earth, but for the purposes of solving todays crossword by Derek Bowman and Sarah Keller, lets just say that our sun is stationary and central to our solar system and that the Earth revolves around it. You dont have to believe it, but it will go a long way toward helping you finish the puzzle.

title: A Mobster, a Family and the Crime That Wont Let Them Go
description: He was once a feared member of the New England underworld, a specialist in robbing armored cars. At 80, he was years out of prison. But could his life of crime ever be behind him?

title: Uber Limits Loss to $708 Million in First Quarter
description: Uber has spent billions to upend the transportation industry. Now, at least for the moment, it is burning slightly less cash in that effort.

title: Man Stabbed in Portland While Coming to Aid of 2 Girls Shifts Focus to Them
description: He was held up as a hero without a cape  the sort of brave, compassionate human being whose actions while on board a Portland light-rail train last week made his mother proud.

title: Refugees and Terrorism, or Refugees and Lost Opportunity?
description: Damien Cave, our Australia bureau chief, shares insights on global news, local recommendations and feedback from readers in this weekly newsletter. To receive it in your inbox, sign up here.

title: Fargo Season 3, Episode 7: The World Is Wrong
description: On this season of Fargo, Michael Stuhlbarg plays Sy Feltz, a character that references both Stan Grossman, the right-hand man to Jerry Lundegaards father-in-law in the Coen brothers Fargo, and Sy Ableman, the gentle-toned widower who runs off with the wife of Stuhlbargs character in the Coens A Serious Man. The fusion seemed superficial at first, another in an ongoing series of hat-tips from creator Noah Hawley to his source of inspiration.

title: Philippine Military Kills 11 of Its Soldiers in Errant Airstrike
description: MANILA  An airstrike by the Philippine military killed 11 of the countrys own soldiers and injured seven others as the government struggled to take back the southern city of Marawi from insurgents loyal to the Islamic State, officials said on Thursday.

title: Pardon My Sweat, and Pass the Borscht
description: Sweat.

title: Eric Goode, a New York Night-Life Impresario, Takes On Trump
description: Eric Goode, 59, is a New York entrepreneur who is an owner of downtown establishments like the Bowery Hotel and the Waverly Inn. He was a creator of Area, the art-gallery-nightclub from the 1980s. He is also a conservationist with something of an obsession for turtles.

title: At Home in Rome
description: For old-school Roman cuisine, these places are in top form. At the tourist-free end of Trastevere, Ristorante la Tavernaccia da Bruno (Via G. Da Castelbolognese; 63; 39-06-581-2792) serves all your classic dishes but also has great ravioli and vignarola. Call for reservations; the secret has long been long out.

title: What to Read Before You Head to Rome
description: To many travelers, visiting Rome is akin to experiencing magic. The reputation is deserved  it is hard to walk through sites like the Colosseum and not be reminded of the citys former splendor, to be struck by its air of romance and mystery. But Rome has evolved, even though our imagination of the Eternal City has not. These books explore the culture, art and grandeur of ancient Rome, but also bring visitors to the present, including a guided tour by a former art critic and a deep exploration of one fictional Italian family.

title: My Rome: Still a Classic Beauty
description: A few hours after landing in Rome, I crossed the Tiber River toward Trastevere, the neighborhood where I lived more than 15 years ago. The river still slithered with reflections of orange lamppost light that reminded me of dragon scales. A familiar cacophony of droning scooters, clanging plates and stray laughter hit me as I skirted the dinner crowd angling for a seat at Trattoria Da Enzo. The gravity of past destinations pulled me around familiar corners and brought me to my old apartment building next to Santa Cecilia, the centuries-old church and convent. All was as I had left it. And now I wanted to leave it.

title: Chinese Maker of Ivanka Trumps Shoes Looks for Cheaper Labor
description: DONGGUAN, China  The Chinese factory workers who make shoes for Ivanka Trump and other designers gather at 7:40 every morning to sing songs.

title: Masahiro Tanaka Takes a Step Back as the Yankees Lead Shrinks
description: BALTIMORE  The Baltimore Orioles were masters of seduction on Wednesday night. They patiently watched first pitch after first pitch from Masahiro Tanaka, perhaps giving him the idea that he could steal a strike.

title: Climate Change, Kabul, Theresa May: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Mets Pitchers Were on a Roll. Their Ace Brings It to a Halt.
description: Mets Manager Terry Collins has a knack for taking a sport as complex and volatile as baseball and reducing it to its simplest form.

title: With Another Quick Burst, Penguins Escape the Predators
description: PITTSBURGH  Pekka Rinne tries to expunge subpar performances by visualizing good ones, of which he has had plenty for the Nashville Predators during these playoffs. He recalls the saves he has made, the teams he has foiled.

title: The U.S. Is the Biggest Carbon Polluter in History. It Just Walked Away From the Paris Climate Deal.
description: The United States has emitted more planet-warming carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than any other country. Now it is walking back a promise to lower emissions.

title: Mr. Mets Obscene Gesture Makes a Tough Season Even Crazier
description: A bad night for the Mets on the field only got worse when the clubs longtime mascot, Mr. Met, was caught on video making an obscene gesture toward a fan in the late stages of the Mets 7-1 loss to the Milwaukee Brewers at Citi Field on Wednesday.

title: Houston Astros, With Six Home Runs, Win Their Seventh Straight
description: George Springer reached base in all six plate appearances and hit two of Houstons season-high six home runs to lead the visiting Astros to their seventh straight victory, 17-6, over the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: My Name Is Emily and The Tunnel
description: A Dublin teenager and her only friend go on a road trip to save her father in My Name Is Emily, starring Evanna Lynch. And The Tunnel, the British-French version of The Bridge, prepares for a second season.

title: Word + Quiz: disputatious
Fasting and Food for Ramadan
description: Ramadan began Friday evening in the United States, and on Saturday in other parts of the world. For 30 consecutive days, many of the 1.8 billion Muslims around the world will fast, eating each evening after the sun goes down and squeezing in a predawn meal before it rises again.

title: Hidden Away for 28 Years, Tiananmen Protest Pictures See Light of Day
description: For nearly 28 years, David Chen hid away a treasure chest of black-and-white photographs that he took of the protest movement that erupted at Tiananmen Square in Beijing in the spring of 1989.

title: Buffons Last Hurdle: A Champions League Crown
description: TURIN, Italy  It was late one Saturday night when Nevio Scala, the manager of Parma, made his way to Gianluigi Buffons hotel room. He wanted to ask Buffon a question, even if he knew what the answer would be.

title: Latin American Pictures of the Year
description: Despite the challenges facing photojournalism, the winners of the latest Pictures of the Year Latam competition show how they are surging forward by staying true to their vision.

title: The Womb Is No Protection From Toxic Chemicals
description: Until a few decades ago, the popular but falsely reassuring belief was that babies in the womb were perfectly protected by the placenta and that children were just little adults, requiring no special protections from environmental threats. We now know that a host of chemicals, pollutants and viruses readily travel across the placenta from mother to fetus, pre-polluting or pre-infecting a baby even before birth.

title: Rule-Benders Require New Rules
description: President Trump blurted a telling remark in a presidential debate when he was accused of failing to pay income taxes: That makes me smart.

title: Trump and Merkel Hate Each Other. So What?
description: BERLIN  The Atlantic is rough these days, as stormy disregard blows from the United States to Europe and back. After President Trump attacked Germanys trade practices, Chancellor Angela Merkel told a campaign rally in Munich that the times we can completely rely on others are somewhat over and that we Europeans must take our destiny into our own hands. Mr. Trump reacted with a tweeted threat, citing Germanys failure to meet NATOs military spending goals, saying this will change.

title: Disarming the Domestic Abuser
description: Progress on gun control has been glacially slow, and on the federal level nonexistent. Even so, its worth noting and celebrating laws enacted in four states this year to deal with one of the grimmest aspects of the nations firearms carnage  the murders of about 50 women each month, shot to death by current or former intimate partners. Many had been the victims of repeated domestic abuse. Some had obtained court protection orders that proved no defense against the fury of an abuser who came armed.

title: Oh Dear. The Trumps Keep Multiplying.
description: The kids are not alright.

title: The Complexities of James Comey
description: There is no other way to put it: Former F.B.I. Director James Comey tragically botched the investigation into Hillary Clinton, no doubt playing a part in her losing and Donald Trumps being elected.

title: Has the Democratic Party Gotten Too Rich for Its Own Good?
description: During his primary campaign against Hillary Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders, a self-proclaimed socialist, lived up to the grand Democratic tradition of favoring the underdog at the expense of the rich.

title: MoMAs Makeover Rethinks the Presentation of Art
description: The final design for the Museum of Modern Arts $400 million expansion project, which will be officially unveiled on Thursday, is striking and provocative less because of its look than its implicit message: MoMA isnt modern yet.

title: Latin American Pictures of the Year
description: A Portuguese photographer, Daniel Rodrigues  who only five years ago was unemployed and had to sell his gear to buy food and pay the rent  has been named Ibero-American Photographer of the Year in the fourth POY Latam contest. Santi Palacios of Spain was awarded second place and Andres Kudacki of Argentina took third.

title: Questions for: The Motive in a Manhattan Shooting? The Statue of Liberty
description: Article: The Motive in a Manhattan Shooting? The Statue of Liberty

title: Covfefe Proves Trump Really Does Have the Best Words, Samantha Bee Says
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. What do you think of it? What else are you interested in? Let us know: thearts@nytimes.com.

title: A Copacabana Protest to Oust Temer
description: Thousands of Brazilians in Rio de Janeiro called on President Michel Temer to resign after revelations of his involvement in another corruption scandal.

title: 36 Hours in Canterbury, England
description: This small city of prayer, stone and stories calls to travelers like a miniature Rome.

title: I Know What Youll Read This Summer
description: Horror isnt what it used to be. In the introduction to Philip Fracassis first collection of short fiction, BEHOLD THE VOID (JournalStone, $29.95), Laird Barron writes: Horror and weird fiction are ascendant a decade and a half into the 21st century; an abundance of market opportunity and artistic talent has inspired a surge of creativity unrivaled in the modern days of the genre. Although it isnt clear precisely what Barron means here  arent an abundance of  talent and a surge of creativity kind of the same thing?  his enthusiasm, for both horror in general and Fracassi in particular, is unmistakable, and his words carry some weight: Barron was himself the genres hot kid 10 years ago and is now, after a bunch of nominations and awards, practically an minence grise. By modern days he appears to mean since the 1970s and 80s, a period he calls the heyday of North American category horror (while citing, among other touchstones, a couple of novels written in the 50s and 60s). So is something truly new happening in horror (and weird) fiction now? And is Philip Fracassi its current avatar?

title: Is a Regret Clause a Good Idea for Cases of Academic Dishonesty?
description: To what extent is plagiarism or any form of academic dishonesty common in your school? Have you ever copied someone elses work and turned it in as your own? If so, were you caught in the act?

title: Paris Poisoners and a Pioneering Female Detective: Your True Crime Books for the Beach
description: If mystery novels appeal to the credulous child in me, true crime stories speak to my inner voyeur. In reading this current batch of books, Ive walked alongside a prisoner on her way to her execution, learned how to poison a wineglass and watched a kings mistress do away with her rival. And thats only from the first book on my list: CITY OF LIGHT, CITY OF POISON: Murder, Magic, and the First Police Chief of Paris (Norton, $26.95), Holly Tuckers stylish study of crimes committed by the high and mighty during the 72-year reign of the Sun King, Louis XIV.

title: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar: By the Book
description: The basketball star and author of Coach Wooden and Me says he looks forward to anything written by Walter Mosley: Id be very happy if he wrote a novel every week.

title: When Is a Back Channel a Problem?
description: David Sanger examines the mounting reports of secret communications with Russia by the Trump transition team.

title: Teju Cole Pairs Text and Image to Explore the Mysteries of the Ordinary
description: BLIND SPOTBy Teju ColeIllustrated. 332 pp. Random House. $40.

title: For a City Family, a Lakeside Second Home Beckons
description: Five years ago, when their first child was a baby, Daniel and Megan Parker rented a two-bedroom on the Upper West Side. Now they have three children.

title: Democrats Bid to Regain Hold on House Begins in California
description: VISTA, Calif.  Representative Darrell Issa was 2,500 miles away from his Southern California home the other day, on a fund-raising mission to Florida. Outside his congressional district office here, a light drizzle fell from the sky. It was a weekday morning.

title: A History of Secret U.S. Channels, From Jefferson to Kushner
description: WASHINGTON  There was Robert F. Kennedys still-mysterious phone call with an Izvestia correspondent, actually a Soviet spy, on Dec. 1, 1960, signaling that his brother, the president-elect, wanted to change the nature of the United States relationship with its Cold War adversary. It wasnt exactly a success: First came the Bay of Pigs, then the Cuban missile crisis.

title: Paris Agreement, MoMA, N.B.A. Finals: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The Daily: Understanding the Paris Climate Deal
description: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: On iPhone or iPad | On Android via RadioPublic | Via Stitcher

title: Had a Job Interview but No Callback? Heres What to Do Next Time
description: Days have passed since your job interview, and no ones called or emailed.

title: Morning Agenda: Will Trump Pull U.S. From Paris Accord?
description: Set your alarms: At 3 p.m. today, President Trump finally answers the question of whether the United States will withdraw from the Paris climate accord.

title: Editorial Contest Winner | Losing the Internet
description: We are honoring each of the Top 10 winners of our Fourth Annual Student Editorial Contest by publishing an essay a day. You can find them all here.

title: At the Movies, the Beach Is the Ultimate Freedom. And in Life?
description: Its summer, even if it doesnt feel like it yet in New York. To get ourselves in the warm-weather spirit, we went to see Baywatch, the new big-screen reboot of the 1990s TV series, starring Dwayne Johnson and Zac Efron as crime-solving lifeguards. We expected just to gawk at the hard bodies and giggle at the corny jokes  and we did that  but we were surprised that the film had a harder edge. It treated the beach like a prison yard, a place to be patrolled and policed, not for fun and frolicking. It left us thinking about the allocation of public spaces and how our own personal histories are tied up in how we experience the beach.

title: Why Troubles at a Midsize Italian Bank Worry the E.U.
description: FRANKFURT  Some banks go to the international markets when they need money for a big deal. Monte dei Paschi di Siena, one of Italys biggest lenders, tapped its own loyal customers.

title: 1967: Argentine Opinion Polls to Replace Congress
description: Buenos Aires  The military government plans to use the Argentine press and public opinion polls as a substitute for the congress which has been dissolved and the political parties which have been banned.

title: New York Today: Hes Your (Ferry) Captain
description: Updated, 9:58 a.m.

title: As Trump Exits Paris Agreement, Other Nations Are Defiant
description: UNITED NATIONS  Leaders from around the world maintained a defiant front on Thursday after President Trump announced that he would withdraw the United States from the Paris Agreement.

title: PPG Drops Its Pursuit of Akzo Nobel
description: LONDON  The American paint and chemicals giant PPG Industries said on Thursday that it had dropped its monthslong pursuit of Akzo Nobel, the Dutch maker of Dulux paint, after failing to persuade its rivals management to engage in merger talks.

title: Movers: Deere to Expand Global Footprint, and China Guides Currency Higher
description: Were following major developments in the markets throughout the day.

title: 5 Must-See Shows if Youre in New York This Month
description: Its beginning to look a lot like summer. So go out and play, already, or better yet, go see a play. Those two pieces of advice are not mutually exclusive this month, which offers a happy assortment of open-air fare, a creepy comedy for those in the mood to be properly scared and  for the nonpassive theatergoer with itchy feet  the chance to get lost in site-specific wonderlands.

title: Learning Dance From Photographs: David Gordons Muybridge Solo
Devon Teuscher, a Poet in Ballet Shoes, Takes On Swan Lake
description: Devon Teuscher knows, perhaps more than most, that being a dancer for American Ballet Theater is a waiting game. Now a soloist, she joined the company as an apprentice about 10 years ago.

title: California Today: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar on the Wisdom of John Wooden
description: Good morning.

title: Climate Losers
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Ex-Obama Officials Find Theres No Place Like Their Old Law Firms
description: When a new administration comes to Washington, top government regulators flock to the exits to find new jobs, but they seldom have to look very far.

title: Donald Trump Wont Move Embassy to Jerusalem, at Least for Now
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump signed an order keeping the American Embassy in Tel Aviv rather than moving it to Jerusalem as he promised during last years campaign, aides said Thursday, disappointing many Israel supporters in hopes of preserving his chances of negotiating a peace settlement.

title: Maybe Private Russian Hackers Meddled in Election, Putin Says
description: MOSCOW  Shifting from his previous blanket denials, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested on Thursday that patriotically minded private Russian hackers could have been involved in cyberattacks last year that meddled in the United States presidential election.

title: Again a Train Delay? We Feel Your Pain!
description: Like most New Yorkers, the team members at The New York Timess Metro desk have a lot to say about the subways. Wendell Jamieson, the Metro editor, likes to recall his childhood experiences riding the subway in the 1970s, such as the time he, his mother and his sister had to escape a smoke-filled, burning 6 train and walk along the tracks until they were able to emerge at 77th Street. (We took some oxygen from the ambulance, which was very exciting, Mr. Jamieson recalled. Then we just walked over and took another line home.)

title: Inside Lisa Fines Upper East Side Apartment
description: Inspired by elements of Hollywood Regency, the fabric designer likes to layer  a lot.

title: In One Fabric Designers Home, a Lesson on Layering Prints
description: When Lisa Fine is about to move to a new home, she often entertains a fantasy that for her qualifies as wild: embracing the solid lacquered furniture, bold lines and sumptuous textures of Hollywood Regency. I admire Dorothy Draper and Billy Haines just so much, says the fabric designer, in a Mississippi drawl gooey as mud pie. So I think to myself, O.K., this is the moment that I am going to do it, really do it.

title: Macedonia Has New Government, but Rocky Road Ahead
description: SKOPJE, Macedonia  After two years of a deepening political crisis marked by a corruption scandal and a violent confrontation with an angry mob in Parliament in April that left several officials bloodied, Macedonia has a new government for the first time in more than a decade.

title: Third Gravitational Wave Detection, From Black-Hole Merger 3 Billion Light Years Away
description: The void is rocking and rolling with invisible cataclysms.

title: Trump Rule Could Deny Birth Control Coverage to Hundreds of Thousands of Women
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration has drafted a sweeping revision of the governments contraception coverage mandate that could deny birth control benefits to hundreds of thousands of women who now receive them at no cost under the Affordable Care Act.

title: When Your Mail App Is a Snoop
description: Q. Why is the mail app on my Android phone asking for permission to use my contacts and calendars? I dont feel comfortable giving that access and it feels like an invasion of privacy, but the app doesnt seem to work otherwise.

title: Ex-British Party Leader Is Pulled Into Trump Campaign Inquiry
description: LONDON  Nigel Farage, the former leader of the U.K. Independence Party, ridiculed a published report on Thursday that suggests United States investigators think he may be able to shed light on any possible collusion between Russia and Donald J. Trumps presidential campaign.

title: Daily Report: Twitter Makes the News a Little Dumber
description: If there is one thing to know about Farhad Manjoo, the technology columnist for The New York Times, it is that he uses Twitter. A lot. So if anyone would know a thing or two about what appears on Twitter, it would be Farhad.

title: Japan and an Anti-Crime Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Aerial America Turns Its Birds Eye on New York
description: One of the most visually adventurous shows on television is the Smithsonian Channel series Aerial America, and it returns on Sunday, June 4, with an expanded mission that begins in New York. The series builds its episodes entirely with aerial photography, a technique that it has been using to tour the United States one state at a time. But its new episodes go both local and international: Future subjects include Ireland and New Zealand.

title: The Choreographer Vicky Shick Explores Drama With the Body
description: The dance world has many local treasures, and one gem is the choreographer Vicky Shick. As part of the second annual Lumberyard in the City festival at the Kitchen, Ms. Shick presents Let It Linger, a new work in which shes intent on inching closer to a different side of her artistry: character and drama. Ms. Shick can steal a scene with the seemingly simple act of raising an arm, but here, shes curious about the possibility of drama  fake and real  combined with dedication to detail and form. And there is her reverence for, as she described in an email, a trust in actual movement and how the body does it. Im old-fashioned that way!

title: Columbias New Harlem Museum Opens, With Art From Its Neighbors
description: New York, New York, is the city so nice it got two of everything: two baseball teams, two decrepit airports and now two riverside art galleries designed by the Italian architect Renzo Piano. His Whitney Museum of American Art has packed in visitors since the spring of 2015, spellbound as much by its balconies and switchback staircases as by its light-filled, column-free galleries. Now it has a fraternal twin a hundred blocks north: the Lenfest Center for the Arts, which serves as a new hub for Columbia Universitys art, film, theater and writing programs. Both rise eight stories beside the Hudson River, though the Lenfest is a bit farther inland. To reach the Whitney, you walk past former meatpacking warehouses that now sell thousand-dollar cashmere sweaters; the Lenfest, for its part, is a stones throw from that Fairway with the walk-in freezer.

title: Northside Festival Adds Activism and Politics to the Music
description: The Northside Festival has grown from a sprawling, centerless but small affair into a sprawling, slightly more centered and improbably huge event  Brooklyns version of SXSW. From Wednesday, June 7, to Sunday, there will be an innovation series, with speakers from the worlds of new media, entertainment, marketing, activism and politics, including Mayor Bill de Blasio. And as always, there will be music, so much of it that Northside is beginning to resemble the old CMJ festival, which was for many years the most important accounting of musical taste in the city.

title: Angels in America, the Opera, in New York
description: When I first learned that the eminent Hungarian composer Peter Eotvos was adapting Tony Kushners two-part epic, Angels in America, into an opera, it struck me as a foolhardy idea. Those teeming parts, which together last some seven hours, are run through with Mr. Kush-ners arresting dialogue, in which characters dispense impassioned political diatribes and lots of gallows humor. But Mr. Eotvos knew what he was doing  the opera had an acclaimed 2004 premiere in Paris, and its New York premiere, presented by the New York City Opera, begins Saturday, June 10, in the Rose Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Alexander Calder at the Whitney: Hypermobility and Shifting Perspectives
description: A delightful feature of many Alexander Calder works is that they can move. His dangling mobiles can twirl and shake in air, making their shadows dance  and making viewers aware of their own shifting perspectives. But in the years since Calders death in 1976, the need to preserve and protect his works has often meant keeping them still.

title: Marvins Room Makes Its Broadway Debut with Janeane Garofalo and Lili Taylor
description: Scott McPhersons breakout play, the deathbed comedy Marvins Room, came into the world as the AIDS epidemic raged. He wrote it before he got sick, but he was in the painful throes of the disease when the show made its Off Broadway premiere in 1991 and was just 33 when he died the following year.

title: Bill Nye: Science Guy: Fighting for the Right to Use Facts
description: On Friday, June 9, the 2017 Human Rights Watch Film Festival begins at Lincoln Center and IFC Center, offering worthy documentaries about struggle and oppression. For example, Erik Ljungs The Blood Is at the Doorstep concerns the fallout when a black man is killed by a Milwaukee policeman; Sophia and Georgia Scotts Lost in Lebanon is about a country facing a million arriving refugees.

title: Driven: 2017 Lincoln Continental
description: Lincoln has brought back one of its signature models, the composed Continental, last seen for 2002, and it enters a competitive luxury market.

title: Video Review: After 15-Year Break, Lincoln Continental Returns With Style
description: The Continental name carries gravitas. So much, in fact, that its easy to forget that Lincoln hasnt used the nameplate since 2002. Its like realizing that Team Flakes hasnt been available in the grocery store for years.

title: How to Be Mindful Holding a Baby
description: Being mindful while holding a baby can be an incredibly gratifying, renewing and sometimes challenging mindfulness practice. Babies cycle through various states of being throughout their days and nights. How you are in relationship to a baby in these various states is truly a practice in everyday life. It can be helpful to remember that whatever state of being that your baby is in at any particular moment, it is not a permanent condition. Nothing is.  Nancy Bardacke, founding director of Mindfulness-Based Childbirth and Parenting.

title: The Leftovers Leads Televisions Musical Golden Age
description: The Leftovers is not only the best thing to watch on TV right now, but its also the best thing to listen to.

title: Food Allergies Found in Less Than 4 Percent of Americans
description: Some 3.6 percent of Americans  fewer than one in 25  have at least one food allergy or intolerance, according to a new report. Those numbers are lower than many earlier estimates.

title: Chondroitin Eases the Pain of Knee Arthritis
description: Patients with osteoarthritis of the knee who were treated with high-quality, prescription-grade chondroitin got as much pain relief after six months as those treated with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug, a new clinical trial has found. They also showed similar improvements in function, such as the ability to walk distances and perform daily activities.

title: A New Play by Lynn Nottage, and More, Coming Soon to the Public Theater
description: Lynn Nottage, whose Pulitzer Prize-winning Sweat had its premiere Off Broadway at the Public Theater this season before transferring to Broadway and earning a Tony Award nomination for best play, seems to be taking little time to bask in her recent success.

title: Parents Wont Pay for Harvard After a Year Off to Help the Poor
description: I am a high school senior who got into Harvard. I want to go, but I would like to take a gap year and work for an antipoverty program first, then start college in September 2018. The admissions office is fine with this. But my parents are freaking out. They say that unless I start college this fall, they will not pay for it. They are afraid that if I interrupt my education, I wont go back, which is crazy. I am trying to be mature, but our conversations turn into screaming matches. Please help!

title: Gun Deal in Jeopardy for Turkish Guards Who Beat Protesters
description: WASHINGTON  The day before armed guards from the Turkish presidents security detail violently attacked a group of peaceful protesters here last month, the State Department notified Congress of its intention to license the sale of $1.2 million worth of semiautomatic handguns to the security force.

title: You Look Familiar. Now Scientists Know Why.
description: The brain has an amazing capacity for recognizing faces. It can identify a face in a few thousandths of a second, form a first impression of its owner and retain the memory for decades.

title: 3 Books That Help Make Sense of the Climate Change Debate
description: As President Donald J. Trump prepares to withdraw the United States from the Paris climate agreement, here are three books that help illuminate some of the issues involved in this divisive subject.

title: Were Hiring a Motion Designer/Video Editor
description: Join The New York Times Snapchat Discover Team

title: A Sympathetic Juan Martn del Potro Advances at the French Open
description: PARIS  Nicols Almagro and Juan Martn del Potro were struggling to move, but when Almagro stopped completely, it produced one of the most moving scenes in recent French Open memory.

title: Inside The Daily With Michael Barbaro
description: The New York Times has a new daily podcast. Twenty minutes a day, five days a week, powered by New York Times journalism and hosted by Michael Barbaro, The Daily began airing just after Donald J. Trumps inauguration.

title: Et Tu, Mr. Met? Another Mascot Behaving Badly
description: Theyre adorable creatures who liven up sports events for young and old alike. Whats not to like about mascots?

title: Read the Draft Rule That Could Limit Birth Control Coverage
description: This draft rule prepared by the White House and H.H.S. would greatly expand the exemptions provided to corporations and insurance companies that claim a moral opposition to contraception.

title: The Best TV Shows and Movies New to Netflix, Amazon and More in June
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: In a Brief Prep School Career, a Growing List of Sexual Misconduct Allegations
description: Frederic Lymans prep school teaching career spanned just six years, and four schools.

title: Hours After Fires, 36 Bodies Are Found at Manila Casino
description: MANILA  Thirty-six bodies were found at the biggest hotel-casino in the Philippines after a gunman carrying a container of gasoline set fires and touched off a mass panic  hours after the authorities said that only the assailant had died.

title: The Paris Climate Deal: What You Need to Know
description: President Trump announced Thursday that he would pull the United States out of the Paris climate accord. The decision makes good on a campaign promise and aligns with Mr. Trumps America first message. It is also a major setback for the worldwide effort to combat global warming.

title: In Coral Skeletons, Microscopic Portraits of Resilience?
description: Coral reefs are sprawling, intricate ecosystems that house an estimated 25 percent of all marine life and can sometimes be seen from space. Yet they are formed by a process invisible to us.

title: Inside the (Very Big) Head of Mr. Met
description: I know. You think I dont know?

title: A Year of Picture Prompts: Over 160 Images to Inspire Writing
description: Update, Feb. 15, 2019: Learn more about how to use our 1000s of writing prompts by watching our free on-demand webinar: Give Them Something to Write About: Teach Across the Curriculum With New York Times-Inspired Daily Prompts.

title: How a Galpagos Bird Lost the Ability to Fly
description: The birds of the Galpagos Islands are still playing a role in helping us understand evolution.

title: Fyre Was Bad. For the Concert Industry, This One Could Be Worse.
description: For the concert industry, the disastrous failure of the Fyre Festival in the Bahamas was an outlier  a sad spectacle, but an isolated one.

title: Democrats Sought Inquiry of Testimony by Sessions at His Confirmation Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  Two Democratic senators disclosed on Thursday that they had asked James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, to open a criminal investigation into whether Attorney General Jeff Sessions perjured himself when he falsely said at his confirmation hearing that he did not have communications with the Russians last year.

title: White House Waivers May Have Violated Ethics Rules
description: The Trump administration may have skirted federal ethics rules by retroactively granting a blanket exemption that allows Stephen K. Bannon, the senior White House strategist, to communicate with editors at Breitbart News, where he was recently an executive.

title: The Bears Ears Monument
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Can Represent Gold Trader in Iran Sanctions Case, Judge Says
description: Despite posing potential conflicts of interest, Rudolph W. Giuliani and another prominent lawyer were allowed on Thursday to continue to represent a Turkish-Iranian gold trader facing federal charges in Manhattan.

title: 19 Fathers Day Gift Suggestions, From $15 to $470
description: It is always a challenge to buy something for Dad, but with this efficient gift guide, there is no need to panic as June 18 approaches.

title: Frick Collection Expands Pay-What-You-Wish Hours
description: The Frick Collection has announced an expansion of its pay-what-you-wish hours. Starting in July, visitors will be able to name their price of admission on Wednesdays, from 2 p.m. to 6 p.m.

title: Trump Will Withdraw U.S. From Paris Climate Agreement
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump announced on Thursday that the United States would withdraw from the Paris climate accord, weakening efforts to combat global warming and embracing isolationist voices in his White House who argued that the agreement was a pernicious threat to the economy and American sovereignty.

title: Trump Awarded a New Chinese Trademark, This Time for Catering
description: President Trump and his daughter Ivanka could sell jewelry and wedding dresses and provide catering services in China under new trademarks granted in recent days by Beijing.

title: What We Learned About the Warriors in Game 1 of the N.B.A. Finals
description: In a postseason in which they have seen little to no competition, the Golden State Warriors kept right on rolling and tied the N.B.A. record for consecutive postseason wins at 13 with a 113-91 drubbing of the Cleveland Cavaliers in Game 1 of the N.B.A finals.

title: A Movie Poster Body-Shamed Snow White, and Chlo Grace Moretz Was Appalled
description: When a movie poster suggested that an overweight Snow White was no longer beautiful, it met with backlash from all corners  including from the actress who stars in the film.

title: Exxon Vote on Climate Change Puts Other Companies on Notice
description: Shareholders of the oil giant Exxon Mobil have finally won a long-sought climate change victory. Over 60 percent of them backed a move that forces the $340 billion company to ramp up global-warming disclosure, up from under 40 percent in a similar attempt last year. Exxon already embraces the debate more than most. But shareholders want the company to be more forthcoming. Holdouts among their industry peers will have to follow or risk investor ire.

title: Review: Captain Underpants, Pretty Much What Youd Expect
description: Superintendents know that the job of school principal is one of the toughest to fill in the education world. It will be a lot more so now that moviegoing children and taxpayers will expect principals to run around in their underwear battling giant toilets.

title: Review: A Powerful Newcomer Plays an Outcast in Sami Blood
description: Sami Blood relies so much on the expressive face of its lead actress, the powerful newcomer Lene Cecilia Sparrok, that at times it might as well be wordless. The film, the feature debut of Amanda Kernell, concerns Scandinavias indigenous Sami people, who faced systemic discrimination in Sweden in the 1930s.

title: Popular People Live Longer
description: I often hear from teenagers that one of their greatest goals is to obtain more Instagram followers than anyone they know. Even some adults appear obsessed with social media, tracking the number of retweets on their Twitter profiles or likes on Facebook. This type of status-seeking might be easily dismissed as juvenile or superficial, but theres more to it.

title: George Soros Accuses Viktor Orban of Turning Hungary Into Mafia State
description: LONDON  For the first time since the government of Hungary threatened to shutter the university he founded in Budapest, the American financier and philanthropist George Soros criticized the countrys right-wing prime minister, Viktor Orban, saying he has presided over a mafia state.

title: Harvard Law School Names John Manning Its Next Dean
description: Harvard Law School has a new dean.

title: Back for More! Mr. Met Returns to the Scene, and Mets Lose Again
description: On the fifth anniversary of one of the greatest pitching performances in their history  Johan Santanas no-hitter  the Mets got a start out of Zack Wheeler that is not likely to be recalled even five days from now.

title: No, Covfefe Was Not Trump Speaking Arabic
description: The internet is full of confident people who do not know what they are talking about. The latest example: a conviction spreading in right-leaning social media communities that a garbled tweet by the president  he wrote covfefe  was not a late-night typo but was instead Mr. Trump sending a message to the world in Arabic.

title: We May Not Be Able to Stop a North Korean Missile
description: When the collision with the mock intercontinental ballistic missile occurred on Tuesday afternoon, the Pentagons Missile Defense Agency was filled with excitement and relief. The first full intercept test in three years of the Ground-based Midcourse Defense system was deemed a success. Some proponents of the program have presented the test as proof that the $40 billion system is capable of defending the United States against long-range missiles that could, in the future, be launched by a rogue nation like North Korea.

title: Trumps Stupid and Reckless Climate Decision
description: People say, if all you have is a hammer, then every problem looks like a nail. We should be so lucky. President Trump has a hammer, but all hell use it for is to smash things that others have built, as the world looks on in wonder and in fear. The latest, most troubling example is his decision to obliterate the Paris climate accord: After nearly 200 years of scientific inquiry and over 20 years of patient diplomacy that united every nation save Syria and Nicaragua, we had this afternoons big game-show Rose Garden reveal: Count us out.

title: Review: Tatara Samurai Forges a Man of Honor
description: Yoshinari Nishikoris period action film Tatara Samurai does not skimp with its swordplay, but its narrative arc takes you to a resolution uncommon for its genre. Tatara, from the Japanese word for furnace, is the name of the films principal setting, a rural 16th-century village famous for its ironworks and the craftsmanship of its weaponry. This mountain hamlet is so coveted for its raw materials that it becomes the prize in a turf battle between two warlords.

title: What to Expect as U.S. Leaves Paris Climate Accord
description: President Trump said on Thursday that the United States was officially withdrawing from the Paris climate agreement, following through on a campaign promise and defying fellow world leaders who had pleaded with him to remain a party to the pact.

title: U.N. and Congo Killings
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Bounty Hunter Shootout Kills 3, Raising Questions
description: The two bounty hunters had their guns drawn as they entered a small, glass-enclosed office in a Texas car dealership on Tuesday. Back up! they shouted before trying to tackle a man in a baseball cap sitting at a desk. Gunfire rang out  about 20 shots in six seconds, officials said. Customers and employees ran for cover.

title: Your Next Lesson: Thirst Quenchers
description: Wine can do a lot of things. It can entice, it can seduce. It can reward contemplation and facilitate conviviality and romance. It can make joyous occasions even more festive, and it can offer comfort amid sadness.

title: Thrilling and Joyless? The Polarity of Sweet Riesling
description: Well, this didnt go quite as I had expected.

title: Review: In Vincent N Roxxy, Love Is in the Air, N So Is Fear
description: What starts in violence ends in viciousness, and then some, in Vincent N Roxxy, a movie whose ambition makes up for quite a few of its misfires.

title: U.S. to Leave Paris Climate Accord. What Happens Now?
description: Brad Plumer, a climate reporter for The New York Times, explains the consequences of President Trumps decision today that he will withdraw from the landmark global warming agreement.

title: Review: The Exception Is a Diverting Tale Set Before Nazi Horrors Fully Emerged
description: In recent years, some movies have reopened the World War II files  especially those parts dealing with the Nazi occupation of Europe and the resistance to it  in search of gray areas and moral puzzles rather than black-and-white tales of treachery and heroism. The Exception, a new film based on a novel by Alan Judd, circles back to an older tradition. Apart from the swearing, the nudity and the nonmarital sex, its the kind of suspenseful, romantic melodrama of awakened conscience that might have been made in Hollywood or Britain in the early years of the war, before the worst of its horrors were widely known.

title: Outrage Over Trumps Climate Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: Paris Agreement, Philippines, Vladimir Putin: Your Friday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Review: Power Ballads as Couples Therapy in Band Aid
description: In Band Aid, Anna (Zoe Lister-Jones of TVs Life in Pieces) and her husband, Ben (Adam Pally), are in distress. Both are frustrated artists. Shes a writer who drives for Uber; hes a graphic designer who has taken on corporate work. They feel increasing pressure to have a baby from friends and from Bens mother, none of whom know about Annas miscarriage. Their lives are consumed with petty squabbles.

title: Review: High School Is Still Terrible for a Handsome Devil
description: Less lusty than the Smiths song of the same title, the sweet-natured drama Handsome Devil studies formulaic coming-of-age movies a little too closely. Ned (Fionn OShea), an artistically inclined misfit, is so miserable at his conservative Irish boarding school that he longs to be expelled. His situation does not improve when he meets his soft-spoken roommate, a rugby-playing transfer student named Conor (Nicholas Galitzine). But adolescent preconceptions about jocks and geeks are overcome, and the two form an unlikely friendship challenged by the schools homophobic atmosphere.

title: A New Tolkien Book Was Inspired by the Authors Own Romance
description: Anyone whos been longing for a return to Middle-earth is in luck.

title: The Scope of Hate in 2017
description: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

title: Do You Know Polo?
description: Test your knowledge on how well you know the game.

title: Sense8 Cancellation Is Netflixs Second in a Week
description: Is Netflix about to set forth on a cancellation binge?

title: Gish Jen, on Clannishness and Jared Kushner
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin Lunch Spot Off Times Square Draws Anything but a Tourist Crowd
description: The costumed characters from Times Square tend to come early, so there will be room for their giant heads.

title: The Woman Behind Wonder Woman
description: Patty Jenkins knew expectations would be stratospheric for Wonder Woman, starring Gal Gadot, a former Miss Israel who served as a combat trainer in the Israeli Army. The film (in theaters Friday, June 2) is the summers most anticipated release and also the first time the halter-top-and-hot-pants-wearing superhero, who was introduced in 1941, has had a movie all her own. But Ms. Jenkins, whose only previous feature, Monster, won Charlize Theron an Oscar in 2004, said she felt pressure most intensely from herself.

title: Watch the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic
description: On June 3, 2017, Veuve Clicquot celebrated the 10th Anniversary of the Polo Classic featuring a special performance by Alicia Keys. Check back soon for a full-length replay of the live event.

title: Conservatives on Campus
description: To the Editor:

title: Trump Talks Tough on Trade, but His Team Is Treading Lightly
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has called the Trans-Pacific Partnership deal a rape of the United States. He has scolded Germany for being very bad on trade because it runs a surplus. And in April he said that he was psyched to terminate the North American Free Trade Agreement with Canada and Mexico, only to reverse course.

title: Fabulously Floral
description: Discover how a floral stylist dresses for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic Ros Garden.

title: Classic Twist
description: Discover how a group of friends brings a contemporary spin to classic looks.

title: Patterns Are The New Black
description: See how a jewelry designer mixes unique shapes, colors and patterns for a distinctive look.

title: A Living Room Fit for a King
description: Bronson van Wyck is one of those van Wycks  perhaps youve driven on their Expressway.

title: Peace Efforts May Be Another Casualty of Bombing in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  All around Kabul, the broken glass was being swept and the dead were still being buried on Thursday. They were the most visible signs of the toll taken by the huge truck bombing in the capital the day before, but another casualty of the violence may yet come into view: a new attempt to move toward peace negotiations with the Taliban.

title: Our Disgraceful Exit From the Paris Accord
description: Only future generations will be able to calculate the full consequences of President Trumps incredibly shortsighted approach to climate change, since it is they who will suffer the rising seas and crippling droughts that scientists say are inevitable unless the world brings fossil fuel emissions to heel.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through June 18. Bureau, 178 Norfolk Street, Manhattan; 212-227-2783, bureau-inc.com.

title: When the Grip Is a Woman (and the Gaffer and the Camera Operator, Too)
description: In her 13 years as a working actress and writer, Zoe Lister-Jones has appeared in 40 TV shows, films and shorts. Three of them had female cinematographers.

title: Review: Esa-Pekka Salonen Brings Mahler to Carnegie, Ever So Coolly
description: Two of the best and most important productions at the Metropolitan Opera in recent years were Janaceks From the House of the Dead, in 2009, and Strausss Elektra, last spring. Both were directed by Patrice Cherau. And both were conducted, brilliantly, by Esa-Pekka Salonen.

title: Midnight Return and Becoming Bond: The Smuggler and the Spy
description: Two streaming services recently debuted two documentaries about very different screen heroes. Sundance Now is showing Midnight Return: The Story of Billy Hayes and Turkey, about the real-life subject of Midnight Express, the sensationalistic 1978 movie about an Americans horrific detainment in a Turkish prison. And Hulu has Becoming Bond, an unusual biopic of George Lazenby, who portrayed James Bond precisely once, in the 1969 film On Her Majestys Secret Service. Contrary to a lot of current conventional wisdom, Service was not just a hit but is also still highly rated by Bond mavens  Mr. Lazenby wasnt divested of the role but walked away from it. How that happened is one of the films many stories, narrated by the man himself.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: How a Shift in U.S. Policy Could Affect Travel to Cuba
description: Though a bill to terminate the remaining travel restrictions to Cuba garnered 55 votes in the Senate last week, President Trump is considering reviving limits on travel to the island, potentially disrupting investments in Cuba made by travel companies since President Barack Obama relaxed restrictions in 2014.

title: Still Reforming Postmodern Dance, California Roots Intact
description: Where would modern dance be without its tradition of difficult women (often from the West Coast of America) who wanted to change the world? Some of them still want to change it today.

title: A Proven Way to Win in Business: Have a Daughter, Hire Women
description: Heres one of the surest routes for men to think of women as equals: Have a daughter.

title: Wild Waves and Quiet Streets: 2 Artists Working From Memory
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art excels at discreet introductions: modest, magnetic shows that enable us to make the acquaintance of artists many of us have barely heard of. Occasionally these shows establish an unexpected reciprocity, their commonalities and differences evolving into a lively dialogue.

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a few last-chance picks of shows that are about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: The Military Dentist With 150,000 Instagram Followers
description: Dr. Nicholas Toscano could just as well have been reviewing a fashion week catwalk  This ones a model, shes a model  rather than looking over his appointments on Tuesday in his dentist office on Central Park South in Manhattan.

title: Review: From the Ashes Sees Coals Dark Present and Dim Future
description: The most telling words in From the Ashes arent spoken by experts (of which there are plenty) but by former coal miners, their worrying spouses and the parents of sick children who have been affected by the industry. Its one thing to hear about regulations and pollution levels and safety standards. Its another to listen to a laid-off father wonder how hell face his family, or watch a mother distraught over her asthmatic son.

title: Review: In Past Life, Family Mysteries and Cosmic Questions
description: Despite a potboiler setup, the Israeli director Avi Neshers film Past Life, inspired by Baruch Milchs memoir Can Heaven Be Void? and by the lives of Mr. Milchs daughters, is both more and less than a simple mystery about one mans actions during World War II.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: Thoreau: American Resister (and Kitten Rescuer)
description: When my father was in high school he worked summers as a lifeguard at Walden Pond. As a kid, I used to hang out there, bird-watching, reading from a slender volume of Henry David Thoreaus journal and soaking up Transcendentalist vibes from the big glacial bowl of clear water ringed with firs and footpaths.

title: Stanley F. Whitman, Who Saw Luxury as a Shopping Center Lure, Dies at 98
description: Stanley F. Whitman, a real estate developer who was hailed as a visionary in the mid-1960s when he had the idea of building an open-air shopping center near Miami Beach for luxury retailers, naming it Bal Harbour Shops, died on May 24 at his home in Miami Shores, Fla. He was 98.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Williamsburgs Short, Crooked Life as a City
description: Q. Was Williamsburg, which is now a neighborhood of Brooklyn, really its own city at one point?

title: Yes, You Can Write More Than One Letter in a Square
description: SPECIAL POST  Some solvers love them, some solvers hate them, but rebus elements are a fact of life when it comes to solving crosswords.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: A Few Months Before Its Official Opening, Tappan Zee Bridge Is Drivable
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y.  Several months remain before it officially opens to long-expectant commuters, but it is now possible to drive across the entire three-mile length of the new Tappan Zee Bridge, a critical crossing in the suburbs of New York City.

title: New Electrical Brain Stimulation Technique Shows Promise in Mice
description: Pulses of electricity delivered to the brain can help patients with Parkinsons disease, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder and possibly other conditions. But the available methods all have shortcomings: They either involve the risks of surgery, from implanting electrodes deep within the brain, or they stimulate from the skulls surface, limiting the ability to target electricity to the right brain areas.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: When the Left Turns on Its Own
description: Bret Weinstein is a biology professor at Evergreen State College in Olympia, Wash., who supported Bernie Sanders, admiringly retweets Glenn Greenwald and was an outspoken supporter of the Occupy Wall Street movement.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: Naked (and Very Close) in the Name of Art
description: On a recent Saturday morning in a desanctified church in Upper Manhattan, 24 people were piled together in a naked fetal hug.

title: In Turkey, a Hunger Strike Divides a Country in Turmoil
description: ANKARA, Turkey  In 1990, Turkish authorities built a monument to human rights in the center of the Turkish capital. Since May 22, nobody has been able to reach it.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Climate Change Is Real: Many U.S. Companies Lament Paris Accord Exit
description: Soon after President Trump announced that the United States would back out of the Paris climate accord, several large companies based in the United States that had supported the international pact said they were disappointed by the decision and would continue their environmental efforts.

title: Paris Agreement, Vladimir Putin, LeBron James: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Trump Gratuitously Rejects the Paris Climate Accord
description: As Donald Trump does his best to destroy the worlds hopes of reining in climate change, lets be clear about one thing: This has nothing to do with serving Americas national interest. The U.S. economy, in particular, would do just fine under the Paris accord. This isnt about nationalism; mainly, its about sheer spite.

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Conflict and its aftermath haunt the books on our recommended list this week, from Music of the Ghosts, the story of a Cambodian refugee who returns home, to Where the Line Is Drawn, a personal journey through the 50 years of occupation that followed the Six Day War, to The Allure of Battle, which suggests nothing less than a new approach to military history. A biography of Ernest Hemingway looks past the legend of masculinity to the man (and writer) underneath, while a study of the Great Lakes dives beneath the surface to offer solutions to the catastrophic problems caused by climate change and invasive species. And The Gift (Or, Techniques of the Body), a smart, playful novel about performance, steers the concept of autofiction in a new direction.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: On Fire Makes Bad Habits Sound Very Sweet
description: The Mississippi-born writer Larry Brown (1951-2004) didnt go to college. Instead, he entered the Marines. When he returned home he drove trucks and forklifts until, in 1973, he joined the fire department in Oxford, Miss. It was a job he would keep for 16 years.

title: From the Archives: The Original Review of Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band
description: This review of the Beatles Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band ran on June 18, 1967, with the headline We Still Need the Beatles, but  The Times current chief pop critic, Jon Pareles, revisited the album on its 50th anniversary this week.

title: Walmart Is Accused of Punishing Workers for Sick Days
description: A report released Thursday by a workers advocacy group says Walmart, the nations largest private employer, routinely refuses to accept doctors notes, penalizes workers who need to take care of a sick family member and otherwise punishes employees for lawful absences.

title: Attendance Drops at Disney Parks Worldwide as Prices Rise
description: LOS ANGELES  In a rare slowdown in one of the hottest areas of the entertainment business, attendance declined at 13 of 14 Disney theme parks around the world in 2016 compared with 2015, according to an independent report released on Thursday. Higher prices, intended in part to ease crowding at certain parks, were a major contributor, analysts said.

title: Noise as a Weapon? Police Use of Sound Cannons Questioned
description: The bulky black squares have been seen at protests in New York for years, sometimes hoisted on the shoulder of a police officer. Though they resemble heavy-duty speakers of the sort used to make announcements at high school football games, they are actually powerful sound cannons known as Long Range Acoustic Devices, or LRADs.

title: Corrections: June 2, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Report Claims Walmart Violations
description: An advocacy group claims to document widespread violations of the Americans with Disabilities Act and the Family and Medical Leave Act.

title: Getting Rid of Bail Is Only the Start
description: Toward the end of last year, Peter Goldberg, who gave up a remunerative career providing legal counsel to hedge-fund and private-equity firms, received a call that put him in Brooklyn Criminal Court at midnight to help a 16-year-old boy charged with petty larceny. The boy had been accused of stealing a pair of sneakers belonging to the teenage son of his foster mother, an act of retaliation, apparently, for the theft of a Game Boy.

title: Fred A. Kummerow, an Early Opponent of Trans Fats, Dies at 102
description: Fred A. Kummerow, a German-born biochemist and lifelong contrarian whose nearly 50 years of advocacy led to a federal government ban on the use of trans-fatty acids in processed foods, a ruling that could prevent tens of thousands of premature deaths a year, died on Wednesday at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 102.

title: Eavesdropping and Unsatisfied
description: Dear Diary:

title: High Times Is Sold to Group That Includes Son of Bob Marley
description: High Times, the magazine that has chronicled the transformation of marijuana use from an underground vice to a major American business, said on Thursday that it had been acquired by a group of investors that includes Damian Marley, son of the reggae star Bob Marley.

title: Roberto De Vicenzo, a Golf Champion Remembered More for a Gaffe, Dies at 94
description: Roberto De Vicenzo, Argentinas finest international golfer, who won the British Open and the first United States Senior Open but was remembered most for one of the games most storied gaffes, died on Thursday in Argentina. He was 94.

title: Two Dogs on a Wild Goose Chase on Governors Island
description: On a brilliant Tuesday morning in mid-May, the Border collies Quinn and Max hopped the 7 a.m. ferry to Governors Island to look for geese.

title: Jiri Belohlavek, Conductor and Leading Interpreter of Czech Music, Dies at 71
description: Jiri Belohlavek, the leading Czech classical music conductor of his generation, died on Wednesday in Prague. He was 71.

title: Bucking Trump, These Cities, States and Companies Commit to Paris Accord
description: Representatives of American cities, states and companies are preparing to submit a plan to the United Nations pledging to meet the United States greenhouse gas emissions targets under the Paris climate accord, despite President Trumps decision to withdraw from the agreement.

title: Hyundai Faces Tough Times as Buyers Go Big
description: Andrew DiFeo can remember a time, just four years ago, when he could hardly keep enough cars on the lot at his Hyundai dealership in Florida. Gasoline was selling for $3.50 or more a gallon, Americans were looking for good fuel economy, and Hyundai seemed to have the answer.

title: Against Warriors, Cavaliers Could Render the Regular Season Meaningless
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Welcome to the 2017 N.B.A. finals, Round 3 of the leagues biggest perpetual mismatch in more than three decades.

title: Could Trump Muzzle Comey? A Look at Executive Privilege
description: WASHINGTON  James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, is scheduled to testify before the Senate Intelligence Committee next Thursday. That prospect raises a question for President Trumps legal and political advisers: Should the president invoke executive privilege to try to block Mr. Comey from talking?

title: Reinhold Hanning, Former Auschwitz Guard Convicted a Year Ago, Dies at 95
description: BERLIN  Reinhold Hanning, one of the last surviving SS guards from the Auschwitz death camp, has died, a year after he was sentenced to five years in jail as an accessory to 170,000 murders during the time he worked at the camp. He was 95.

title: Blue Apron, a Meal Delivery Service, Files for Public Offering
description: Blue Apron was a pioneer in delivering food kits to customers for assembling meals at home. Now it is beating a path to an initial public offering.

title: Uber Says It Just Noticed Error on Pay, but It Was No Secret
description: Uber said last week that it had recently discovered an accounting error that had deprived New York drivers of tens of millions of dollars, and vowed to pay back drivers every cent, with interest.

description: Liberty State Park, N.J.  On June 3, 2017, Veuve Clicquot celebrated the 10th Anniversary of the Polo Classic featuring a special performance by Alicia Keys.

title: Fabulously Floral
description: Discover how a floral stylist dresses for the Veuve Clicquot Polo Classic Ros Garden.

title: In Texas, Some Rare Good News About Cities With Pension Woes
description: Detroit. Stockton. Puerto Rico. The list of places bankrupted by ballooning pension obligations and other debts is growing. But now comes some good news about two cities, Dallas and Houston, that have pulled back from the brink.

title: Classic Twist
description: Discover how a group of friends brings a contemporary spin to classic looks.

title: Patterns Are The New Black
description: See how a jewelry designer mixes unique shapes, colors and patterns for a distinctive look.

title: Ons Jabeur Achieves Victory, and a Milestone, at the French Open
description: PARIS  Just after Ons Jabeur clinched the biggest victory of her career, she was handed a Tunisian flag, which she waved proudly on the red-clay terrain of Court Suzanne Lenglen, the second-largest stadium at Roland Garros.

title: Officers Indictment Makes Good on Prosecutors Plea for Patience
description: A week after a New York City police sergeant shot and killed a woman who had a mental illness in her apartment last October, the Bronx district attorney, Darcel D. Clark, summoned more than two dozen members of the clergy and other community leaders to her office and urged them to give her a chance to investigate the case fully and to hold off on protests.

title: Maines Governor Wants Inmates to Fill Jobs, Not Prison Beds
description: Paul R. LePage, the brash and deeply conservative governor of Maine, has never been seen as an advocate of loosening punishments for criminals. He once joked that drug dealers should be publicly executed. He has seemed, at times, to support racial profiling in the pursuit of drug traffickers. And he has suggested that suspected domestic abusers wear ankle monitors, even if they have not been charged with crimes.

title: Devin Nunes Is Criticized for Keeping Subpoena Power in Russia Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee was strongly criticized on Thursday by the panels ranking Democrat for refusing to give up his subpoena power over the investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election less than two months after announcing he would step away from the inquiry.

title: In Rejecting Popular Paris Accord, Trump Bets on His Base
description: WASHINGTON  By a ratio of more than five to one, Americans in one recent poll said the United States should participate in the Paris climate change agreement that President Trump pulled out of on Thursday. Even a majority of Republicans agreed.

title: Trump Hands the Chinese a Gift: The Chance for Global Leadership
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has managed to turn America First into America Isolated.

title: Sharmila Nicollet Enters a Tournament With an Assist From Social Media
description: Five years ago, shortly before turning 21, Sharmila Nicollet became the youngest Indian woman to qualify for the Ladies European Tour. The accomplishment resonated in her native country, which does not have much of a golfing tradition, particularly for women. Her popularity soon soared to heights usually reserved for star cricket players.

title: Group of Horses
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Memory is a funny thing. Why can I remember the Star Wars villain DARTH MAUL from The Phantom Menace, which came out in 1999, but I cant remember the Sally Fields character of AUNT MAY from the far more recent The Amazing Spider-Man movie? Also, who are you people and has anyone seen my car keys?

title: Review: In The Government Inspector, Dumb and Dumber, Deliciously
description: Oh, the vulgarity, the venality, the small-minded nastiness of those loathsome souls now crowding the stage at the Duke on 42nd Street. But arent they delicious, every last rotten one of them?

title: Ex-Nurse Pleads Guilty to Killing 8 Patients at Ontario Nursing Homes
description: A former nurse pleaded guilty on Thursday to killing eight patients at Ontario nursing homes in what news reports said was among the worst string of serial killings in Canadian history.

title: Trump, Prioritizing Economy Over Climate, Cites Disputed Premises
description: WASHINGTON  In making his case for abandoning the Paris climate accord, President Trump characterized the agreement as an economic straitjacket  one that would impose terrible burdens on Americans by shuttering the coal industry, suffocating growth and redistributing jobs and wealth from the United States to its competitors.

title: Quotation of the Day: Defiant Other Countries Reaffirm Fight Against Climate Change

description: TORONTO  Gary Sanchez has not been bad this season. Yes, he missed a month with a strained biceps, but he carried a respectable .768 on-base-plus-slugging percentage into June and has regularly influenced games with his throwing arm.

title: The Warriors Drub the Cavaliers in a Defeat for Parity
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  So much about the start of the N.B.A. finals on Thursday night felt familiar. It had everything to do, of course, with the two teams that took the court for Game 1 at Oracle Arena: the Golden State Warriors and the Cleveland Cavaliers, back at it for the third straight year.

title: Making a Marriage Magically Tidy
description: I have the reputation of living what Marie Kondo might call a magically tidy life. My tights are rolled like sushi, my tabletops are bare and my kitchen is so clean I could perform surgery in it.

title: In Santiago, a Regal Old Neighborhood Opens Its Doors
description: Until a few years ago, I never spent any time during annual visits to Santiago, Chile, in the neighborhood of Lastarria, a well-heeled belle epoque-style residential district at the edge of downtown. I would gravitate instead to three central neighborhoods; a meal in Vitacura, a cocktail in Bellavista, and a stay in Providencia. Lastarria, a triangular barrio partly closed to traffic by Santa Luca Hill to the west and Parque Forestal to the north, was off my radar. Lately, though, with a half-dozen hotels having opened in Lastarria in the last two years alone, not to mention dozens of new shops and restaurants, its where everyone wants to be.

title: A London Kitchen Turning Out Israeli Street Food
description: Before he became a global brand, Yotam Ottolenghi introduced Londoners to modern Israeli food  a minor trend that has become a phenomenon. His culinary disciples have carried the flag with smart Middle Eastern restaurants like Honey & Co., Jago and Berber & Q.

title: Juventus Enters Champions League Final With More Than a Title at Stake
description: TURIN, Italy  Gonzalo Higuan had been a Juventus player for only a few hours when he was asked the question, the one that transfixes anyone and everyone connected to the club. At Napoli, the team he had just left, they were still flushing jerseys bearing his name into the sewers, mourning what they had lost. In Turin, fans thoughts had already turned to what they might win.
