McMaster and Gary Cohn, wrote the following passage in The Wall Street Journal: The president embarked on his first foreign trip with a cleareyed outlook that the world is not a global community but an arena where nations, nongovernmental actors and businesses engage and compete for advantage.

title: When America Barred Italians
description: Twelve years ago, I began researching a family murder that happened in Southern Italy in the 19th century. It took a decade to find the details of the crime, but the facts I uncovered about the daily life of my ancestors and the racism they faced  even from their own countrymen  were more shocking than the killing. In todays climate of refugee bans and xenophobia, the facts have taken on a new urgency and are even more disturbing to me, as they should be to anyone whose family traces its roots to Southern Italy.

title: The Past 50 Years of Israeli Occupation. And the Next.
description: JERUSALEM  Three months after the 1967 war, Israels ruling Mapai Party held a discussion on the future of the newly conquered territories. Golda Meir, who would become Israels leader a year and a half later, asked Prime Minister Levi Eshkol what he planned to do with the more than one million Arabs now living under Israeli rule.

title: The Best Way to Cool Your Space

title: How New York Is Turning Food Waste Into Compost and Gas

These plastic totems are part of the citys multimillion-dollar campaign to cut down on greenhouse gas emissions and reliance on landfills, and to turn food scraps and yard waste into compost and, soon, clean energy.

title: In These New Activity Books for Kids, Staying Within the Lines Is Decidedly Optional
description: Give a kid a piece of paper and some crayons with the directive to draw something, and the result might be a blank stare. But an activity book packed with doodling prompts, stickers, puzzles, hidden pictures, coloring pages or ideas for art projects can keep brains and hands blissfully busy, even through long summer afternoons  or car and plane trips that seem not just long but endless. The latest batch of these summertime sanity savers has a refreshing design-conscious sensibility, and  unlike Animal Jam or Musical.ly videos  may even end up teaching a youngster a thing or two.

title: How Michael Kelly, Actor on House of Cards, Spends His Sundays

But offscreen, Mr. Kelly, 48  who lives in East River Housing on the Lower East Side of Manhattan with his wife, Karyn, 45, and their daughter, Franke, 7, and son, Clinton, 4  is generally all smiles. I try to leave him in Baltimore, he said of Stamper, who finds himself embroiled this season in some decidedly Trumpian twists and turns. Mr. Kelly and his family are currently squeezed into a sublet across the street from their apartment, which they are renovating.

title: On Irelands Border: That Sad Old Game
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland  When Britain voted last June to leave the European Union, Northern Ireland voted to remain by a clear majority. Along the border with the Republic of Ireland, that majority was even larger, about 64 percent. The referendum was a hard knock for the Borderlanders  a blunt reminder that they are peripheral not only to the geography of Britain but also to the debate about its future. The damage that leaving the European Union could do to their lives and livelihoods was hardly considered in wider Britain.

title: The Romance and Heartbreak of Writing in a Language Not Your Own
description: As a child, Leonora Carrington  painter, fabulist, incorrigible eccentric  developed the disconcerting ability to write backward with her left hand while writing forward with her right. This trick did not go over well with English convent school nuns. Between the world wars, Carrington was thrown out of one school after another for persistently odd behavior. When she came of age, she fled England  and her familys fortune  for France and the Surrealists, for a life crammed with incident and adventure, occasional poverty and steady productivity. She died in Mexico City in 2011, at the age of 94, leaving behind paintings and stories full of strange, spectral charm, in which women undress down to their skeletons and a sociable hyena might venture out to a debutante ball, wearing the face of a murdered maid.

title: Japan, Short on Babies, Reaches a Worrisome Milestone
description: TOKYO  Since Japan began counting its newborns more than a century ago, more than a million infants have been added to its population each year.

title: 1967: A Year in the Life of Idealism and Anarchy
description: IN SEARCH OF THE LOST CHORD1967 and the Hippie IdeaBy Danny Goldberg336 pp. Akashic Books. $25.95.

title: Satires of the Ultrarich, From One of Their Own
description: THE HAVES: Kevin Kwans novel Rich People Problems  new at No. 12 on the hardcover fiction list  concludes a bubbly trilogy about the backbiting and infighting in a ridiculously wealthy Chinese clan. (A movie adaptation of the first book in the series, Crazy Rich Asians, is in preproduction with Warner Brothers.) The aura of gaudy glamour and bling in these books may seem like the stuff of soap operas, but its essentially true to the world in which Kwan was raised  so much so, he has said, that his relatives have no interest in reading his work. Most of my family is completely puzzled by these books, and they dont really understand what the fuss is all about, he told the website Nylon last month. They dont really get the humor, and its just like, Everyone has a hundred million dollars, whats the big deal? or Why is any of this interesting? Thats O.K. with Kwan. Hes not writing for his family anyway. I think people who are going to pick up a book called Crazy Rich Asians or Rich People Problems are looking for the fun and the froth; theyre looking for an escape. Theyre looking for it to be like a fun romp into the lifestyles of the rich and famous, he said. Theyre not looking for Cormac McCarthy.

description: Many business executives have advocated for policies to address climate change. Now that President Trump has decided to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, they ought to stand up.

description: Being asked to spell marocain to win the 2017 Scripps National Spelling Bee seemed barely a challenge for Ananya Vinay.

title: Why I Wrote This Article on Malcolm Gladwells Keyboard
description: The week I graduated from high school, a teacher presented me with a gift: a silver Cross pen engraved with my name. I was surprised and touched. I hadnt felt particularly close to this teacher, who had instructed me in Advanced Placement history and government courses. But I did well on the A.P. exams. He felt pride in my accomplishment, and the gift was his way of expressing that.

description: On this weeks podcast, the actress Debra Winger reads You May Want to Marry My Husband, the heartbreaking essay that Amy Krouse Rosenthal wrote before her death in March.

description: Shopping for an apartment can be a real drag. Who really wants to slog through endless open houses, face off in bidding wars or contend with a co-op board? Wouldnt it be easier if someone else could do it for you, like, say, your mother?

description: To the Editor:

title: The Public Editor Signs Off
description: There probably hasnt been a time in recent American history when the role of the media was more important than now. The Trump administration is drowning in scandal, the country is calcified into two partisan halves. And large newsrooms are faced with a choice: to maintain an independent voice, but one as aggressive and unblinking as the days of Watergate. Or to morph into something more partisan, spraying ammunition at every favorite target and openly delighting in the chaos.

title: From the University of Maryland
description: To the Editor:

title: Spatchcocked Roast Chicken
description: This method, sometimes called butterflying, ensures a more evenly cooked chicken with crisp skin and a juicy interior.

title: A Chicken-Roasting Method All Good Cooks Know
description: Everyones looking for the perfect roast chicken, yet spatchcocking still seems like a secret of those in the know. Suffice it to say, its a skill worth learning, and not just because spatchcocking is a fun word to bandy about with authority.

title: Japans Market Surges, but Analysts Worry of Looming Trouble
description: TOKYO  Japans main stock index surged to an 18-month high on Friday, breaking the 20,000 level for the first time since late 2015.

title: Germany Investigates Audi Emissions in Europe, Widening VW Inquiry
description: BERLIN  German prosecutors have widened a criminal investigation into Volkswagens Audi unit after authorities accused the luxury carmaker of installing a system designed to evade emissions rules in cars in Europe, a major shift for an inquiry that has previously concentrated on the United States.

title: Fruit Flies and Mice to Get New Home on Space Station, at Least Temporarily
description: A bit of science trivia: Did you know that the heart of a fruit fly beats at about the same pace as yours?

title: Bookshelf: Picture Books That Conjure Water Worlds
description: Three friends fish on a meandering river. Oliver, an elephant, nabs a fish with his trunk; Lulu, an owl, uses her claws; but Charlie, a rabbit, cant catch any with his pole. They race boats made of sticks; Charlies loses. His pals cheer him up by building a raft they all fish from. This is Chases third book with these adorably rosy-cheeked, mismatched creatures who overcome snafus and stay friends. With creamy watercolors, loose pen lines and easy storytelling, her outdoorsy life lessons sidle up as gently as a summer breeze.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: From the depths of New Yorks waterways to the most distant stars in its firmament, this annual celebration offers many adventures for children. Three are outdoors: Science in the Square, an exhibit extravaganza in Times Square through Saturday; the multisite Great Fish Count, all day Saturday, where young explorers can don waders and grab nets to help document the regions aquatic species; and, that evening, from 7 to 11, Saturday Night Lights, a chance to stargaze with astronomers and astronauts in Brooklyn Bridge Park. Indoors, at 4 p.m. on Saturday, Alan Alda hosts Flame Challenge: What Is Energy?, an interactive investigation at the N.Y.U. Skirball Center. Also at Skirball, Sunday at 1:30 p.m., is Cool Jobs, an encounter with the hippest of science teachers. (One is a science rapper.) The N.Y.U. Kimmel Center will end the festival on Sunday with two free daylong events: Ultimate Science Sunday, an immersive fair whose activities will include playing soccer with robots, steering underwater rovers and taking a virtual reality tour of the moon; and Science and Storytime, a gathering of authors with cosmic concerns. LAUREL GRAEBER

title: Concord Bicycle Music Adds to Its Catalog, Acquiring Imagem Music Group

description: WASHINGTON  Senators, spies and a president spent years in a pitched battle over how the history is told of one of the most controversial chapters of Americas campaign against terrorism, the detention and interrogation of prisoners in secret C.I.A. jails.

description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: A Family of Three Prefers Stuyvesant Town to Midtown
description: When Julie Beaumont Carey and Joe Carey tell people they live in Stuyvesant Town-Peter Cooper Village, they are often met with amazement. Everyone asks, How did you get in? Mr. Carey said.

title: India, Once a Coal Goliath, Is Fast Turning Green
description: MUMBAI, India  Just a few years ago, the world watched nervously as India went on a building spree of coal-fired power plants, more than doubling its capacity and claiming that more were needed. Coal output, officials said, would almost triple, to 1.5 billion tons, by 2020.

title: Sgt. Pepper Celebration Kicks Off in Liverpool, With a Little Help From International Artists
description: LIVERPOOL, England  Perched on scaffolding several stories above the ground outside the Titanic Hotel here on Thursday  the 50th anniversary of the release of the Beatles landmark album Sgt. Peppers Lonely Hearts Club Band  the painter Gary Jones added the final touches to a giant mural designed by the artist Judy Chicago of the four Beatles engulfed in a circular rainbow.

title: How to Make a Mummy (Accidentally)
description: Theres more than one way to mummify a corpse.

title: The Mummies Medical Secrets? Theyre Perfectly Preserved
description: Hundreds of skeletons have lain scattered around a crypt beneath a church in Vilnius, Lithuania, for centuries. But 23 of these remains are unlike the rest: Flesh wraps their bones, clothes cover their skin, and organs still fill their insides.

title: The Supreme Courts Options in the Travel Ban Case
description: The fight over President Trumps travel ban reached the Supreme Court late Thursday night, in the form of three urgent requests from the Justice Department.

title: At the French Open, Novak Djokovic Struggles and Rafael Nadal Rolls
description: PARIS  After Novak Djokovic won his third-round match at the French Open on Friday afternoon on Court Philippe Chatrier, the crowd rose and cheered, as they often do.

title: Gay Lawmaker, Leo Varadkar, Is in Line to Be Irelands Prime Minister
description: DUBLIN  A gay son of an Indian immigrant is now all but certain to become the next prime minister of Ireland, a country that has rapidly been leaving its conservative Roman Catholic social traditions behind.

title: Best College Degrees for Homeownership
description: Its commencement season, and a new crop of college graduates is entering the job market. How long will it take them to achieve the American dream of homeownership? Realtor.com looked at 336 college degrees to determine which would most quickly put their bearers in a financial position to buy a home.

title: Can China Take the Lead on Climate Change? That Could Be Difficult
description: As the weeks before an autumn summit meeting in Beijing between the presidents of the United States and China ticked down, John F. Kerry, then the American secretary of state, tried to seal a deal on climate change.

title: The Playlist: Foo Fighters Run Amok, and Arcade Fire and Lorde Overindulge
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

title: The Mysterious Case of the Glut in True-Crime TV
description: The crime rate in the United States remains considerably lower than it was a few decades ago, but not on your television. True-crime programs are seemingly everywhere these days, with early June bringing yet another new batch. As with zombie stories and scripted police procedurals, it seems as if this genre has no saturation point.

title: A New Formula to Help Tame Chinas Yellow River
description: Each year thousands of tourists flock to a reservoir along the Yellow River in China to witness a ritual cleansing so violent that it can look as if the earth just exploded. At the end of June and the start of July, for as long as two weeks before the flood season, Chinese officials open large portals along the walls of the Xiaolangdi Dam, releasing clear and muddy water simultaneously from the reservoir above to the river below. It gushes out, and in some years clouds the color of doom ascend beyond the dams walls.

title: Former Penn State President Gets Jail Time in Child Molestation Scandal
description: HARRISBURG, Pa.  A judge on Friday sentenced three former Pennsylvania State University officials, including a former president, to short jail terms followed by home confinement for their roles in the child molestation scandal that rocked the university.

title: The Makings of a Delicious Eton Mess
description: The popular English dessert (a.k.a. pudding in British-speak) Eton Mess, attributed to a yearly celebration at Eton College, is a delectable combination of strawberries, smashed meringues and softly whipped cream. As desserts go, its not daunting to make  just a matter of marinating strawberries with lemon juice, sugar and an optional slosh of liquor. Mess in this context means mixture rather than messy. Even so, you would not exactly call it elegant, though it has universal appeal.

title: Art Dealers Fifth Avenue Co-op Sells for $55 Million
description: The palatial Fifth Avenue apartment where the prominent dealer of Asian art Robert H. Ellsworth lived for more than three decades, until his death in 2014, was finally sold by his estate last month.

title: Exxon Emissions Costs Accounting May Be a Sham, New York State Says
description: For years, Exxon Mobil has insisted that its investment decisions take into account what carbon pollution will eventually cost the company.

title: His Camera Has Ears
description: One night it wasPierre Boulez at Carnegie Hall. On other nights it was John Zorn at the old Knitting Factory, or Devo in Central Park or Anna Netrebko at the Metropolitan Opera House. Maybe it was the punk band Atari Teenage Riot in the legendarilytrashy dressing roomat CBGB, or Ornette Coleman atJazz at Lincoln Center.

title: Police Make Arrest in Theft of Portland Attack Victims Wedding Ring
description: The police in Portland, Ore., arrested a person they say stole the backpack and wedding ring of Rick Best, one of the men who was fatally stabbed last week as he tried to intercede when a man screamed anti-Muslim insults at two women on a commuter train.

title: Rihanna vs. Apple Outshines Warriors vs. Cavs

title: Now Spamilton Really Cant Miss Its Shot to Tease Hamilton
description: If it raps like Hamilton, sings like Hamilton and dances like Hamilton, then it probably is Hamilton.

title: Unknown Edith Wharton Play Surfaces
description: In 2009, a cache of letters from the young Edith Wharton to her governess caused a stir when they turned up at auction. Now, an archive in Texas has yielded another startling Wharton discovery: an entirely unknown play.

title: Jerry Stackhouse: A Life in Movies (Hours and Hours of Movies)
description: TORONTO  Jerry Stackhouse appeared in 1,045 N.B.A. games during his 18-year playing career, and most of those were televised. But many of his quiet, behind-the-scenes moments were captured for posterity, too.

title: Some Things T Editors Are Really Into Right Now
description: Nike is known to outfit professional athletes, but the sportswear brand and a space-obsessed artist are more unexpected partners-in-merch. Nevertheless, five years ago, Tom Sachs collaborated with Nike on a shoe for Tommaso Rivellini, a mechanical engineer at NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., using the same material Rivellini used to invent airbags for Mars rovers. The sneakers quickly became part of the Sachs studio uniform; in time, however, the artist and his cohort discovered that the shoe breaks like a paper clip if its folded too much in the same spot. We put it through all of the usual Nike tests, Sachs notes, but we discovered an unknown unknown.

title: Mark Lee: Swapping Slingbacks for Social Justice
description: The riotous hoots of nearby youngsters threatened to drown out his comments, but Mark Lee was unfazed. Mr. Lee, the former chief executive of Barneys New York, seemed keyed in to their mood in the courtyard of the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center in Greenwich Village.

title: After 37 Die in Attack at Manila Resort, Questions Mount
description: MANILA  The gray smoke that belched for hours from a popular hotel-casino in Manila was initially dismissed by the police as the work of a disgruntled gambler with a bottle of gasoline. But as day broke over the Philippine capital on Friday, investigators discovered dozens of bodies, upending the governments explanation of the fire and raising questions about the identity and motives of someone responsible for one of the countrys largest mass killings.

title: Kathy Griffin Is Being Investigated by the Secret Service, Her Lawyers Say
description: The Secret Service is investigating Kathy Griffin for the photo online of her holding what looks like the decapitated head of President Trump, her lawyers disclosed on Friday.

title: The General Running Dutertes Antidrug War
description: DAVAO CITY, Philippines  Gen. Ronald dela Rosa, chief of the Philippine National Police, knows the value of a public display of remorse. He has been forced to apologize more than once.

title: Review: The Philharmonic Makes Wagners Gods Chillingly Human
description: It began as a compromise, and ended as a triumph.

title: Ahead of Breaking News, a Shoe Story That Fits
description: A labor advocacy group announced on Tuesday evening in Hong Kong that one of its undercover investigators, who had gone missing while probing the production of Ivanka Trump-branded shoes in a Chinese factory, had been detained by the police, and two more of its investigators had disappeared in China. Within a day and a half, The New York Times had published two in-depth articles, one on the disappearances and the other on how Ivanka Trump shoes are made, complete with numerous photos from inside the factory.

title: Spanish Treasures Overlooked in New York Find Love in Madrid
description: MADRID  The treasures of the Hispanic Society of America  works by Goya, Velzquez and El Greco, among other masters  are not a popular tourist draw at the groups Beaux-Arts museum in Washington Heights.

description: Charles Oakley wants his day in court.

title: Inside a Mobsters Bedroom
description: What am I doing in a mobsters bedroom?

title: How Glenn Ligon Is Using Black and Blue to Begin a Dialogue
description: In the beginning was the word: Fragments of prose by James Baldwin, jokes by Richard Pryor and, later, the testimony of a youth wrongly accused of a crime. All have served as the basis for Glenn Ligons series of text paintings and neons exploring race, identity, language and abstraction. Now an Ellsworth Kelly painting, Blue Black (2000), has become the departure point for Mr. Ligons latest project.

title: The Hottest Body Part? For a Sapiosexual, Its the Brain
description: Aboubacar Okeke-Diagne finds internet pornography a little disappointing. The problem is the dialogue: It seems like a lot of pointless small talk.

title: Review: New Yorks Early-Music Scene Is Having a Moment
description: The fast-growing vitality of the early-music scene in New York has seldom been more clearly on display than in the closing days of this season.

title: Mishandled Measles Vaccine Kills 15 Children in South Sudan
description: Contaminated vaccines in a rural village in South Sudan killed 15 children last month and endangered dozens more, according to a statement from the World Health Organization, Unicef and the health ministry of South Sudan.

title: Chinas Role in Climate Change, and Possibly in Fighting It
description: BEIJING  When President Trump announced that he would take the United States out of the Paris climate accord, a treaty to limit global warming, he threw an accusing spotlight on China, the planets biggest emitter of greenhouse gases from fossil fuels and industry.

title: Review: Date My Dad Is Warm, Fuzzy and Has Raquel Welch, Too
description: On Friday night UP TV, a channel that emphasizes family-friendly programs with upbeat messages, begins a series called Date My Dad. Its a harmless show, pleasant even, but it should come with a warning: Do not watch if you are troubled by the fact that time marches inexorably onward.

title: Review: Japan Meets France, Through a Pianists Sensitivity
description: As forms of wordless storytelling, mime and music are sister arts that rarely share a stage. Yet they came together on Thursday evening at Weill Recital Hall. There, the pianist Sara Davis Buechner was joined by the mime dancer Yayoi Hirano in a performance of Jacques Iberts Histoires in which the addition of spare, precise movements and Noh-style masks deepened the musics mystery and whimsy.

title: 11 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times articles from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: Big Bird, Hamptons Dogs and Bronx Gardens
description: Galas were held last week for the Sesame Workshop, the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, Parkinsons Foundation and the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Big Bird, Hamptons Dogs and Bronx Gardens
description: Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit group behind Sesame Street, held a gala on May 31 at Cipriani 42nd Street. The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons hosted a cocktail party on May 27 at the ARF Thrift and Treasure Shop in Sagaponack, N.Y. The Parkinsons Foundation had its 60th anniversary gala on May 31 at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. And the garden held its own black-tie benefit on June 1.

title: Did Trumps Trip Abroad Add Thousands of Jobs? Maybe in Saudi Arabia
description: In his announcement to withdraw from the Paris climate agreement, President Trump squeezed in a credulous claim that his nine-day trip abroad was a boon for jobs at home.

title: To Be Great, America Must Be Good
description: WASHINGTON  Four and a half months is not long, but President Trump has accomplished an extraordinary amount in a short time. With shocking speed, he has wreaked havoc: hobbling our core alliances, jettisoning American values and abdicating United States leadership of the world. Thats a whole lot of winning  for Russia and China.

title: Trumps Incompetence Wont Save Our Democracy
description: Can an autocrat be ridiculous? Can a democracy be destroyed by someone who has only the barest idea of what the word democracy means? Can pure incompetence plunge the world into a catastrophic war? We dont like to think so.

title: Trump Said to Pick Nominees for 2 Positions on Fed Board
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump administration has selected candidates for at least two of the three open positions on the Federal Reserves Board of Governors, according to people with direct knowledge of the decision.

title: Trumps Travel Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: Does Donald Trump Still Think Climate Change Is a Hoax? No One Can Say
description: WASHINGTON  As a businessman, President Trump was a frequent and scornful critic of the concept of climate change. In the years before running for president, he called it nonexistent, mythical and a a total con job. Whenever snow fell in New York, it seemed, he would mock the idea of global warming.

title: A Home for the Olympics
description: To the Editor:

title: View Finder
description: After being forced to brick over his lofts beautiful view of the Hudson River, a man devises a clever replacement. As drawn by Tom Gauld.

title: E. L. Woody, King of the Paparazzi, Dies at 70
description: Charlie Sheen, Lindsay Lohan, Tom Cruise and Paris Hilton were among the scores of celebrities captured by E. L. Woodys roving lens  whether they liked it or not.

title: Even Good Drivers May Be Hampered by Stigma of High-Risk Insurance
description: Good drivers covered by high-risk automobile insurers may find it hard to overcome that stigma when seeking new coverage from a standard insurer, a new analysis suggests.

title: Review: Reanimating an Autistic Artist With Soot and Spit
description: Its a strange medium for an artist to work in, but soot and spit were what James Castle used in place of ink or watercolors, beginning as a child in the early 1900s. Profoundly deaf and autistic, he refused to learn language when he was sent away to school, yet he was resourcefully, voraciously creative.

title: For Carl Reiner and His Fellow Nonagenarians, Death Can Wait
description: The title of Carl Reiners most recent book is Too Busy to Die, and this 95-year-old comedy legend can thank his vivid dreams for inspiring many of the (sometimes wacky) ideas that keep him going.

title: How to Buy a Home
description: Buying a home can seem like a daunting process, but with careful research and determination, the keys to that dream home can be yours. Well help you along your path toward homeownership.

title: 9 TV Shows Well Be Talking About in June
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: Chandraswamy, Who Fell From Favor as a Guru to Celebrities, Dies at 66
description: NEW DELHI  Chandraswamy, a Hindu holy man who counseled such 1980s glitterati as Elizabeth Taylor, the Saudi arms dealer Adnan Khashoggi and the Sultan of Brunei before coming under a barrage of criminal investigations, died here on May 23. He was 66.

title: Latin Pop Thrives, No Bieber Required
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: Western Yunnan Crossing Bridge Noodle
description: This Brooklyn restaurant excels at a deconstructed potage that servers combine at the table.

title: For This Soup, Some Assembly Is Required (and Provided)
description: Once upon a time, there was a scholar who was studying hard for his imperial exams on a small island of Yunnan. So begins the legend of crossing-the-bridge noodles, as written on the wall at Western Yunnan Crossing Bridge Noodle in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

title: How CUNY Became Poetry U.
description: The City University of New York is many things. It is vast. It is accessible to students without a lot of money. It is exceptionally diverse. It is not, however, particularly fancy, the kind of place that oozes exclusivity or prestige.

title: Verse in the City
What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: Binge-Watching Trumps Climate Horror Show
description: There was certainly a lot of buildup. Before President Trump formally announced on Thursday that the United States would pull out of the Paris climate agreement, he teased the public about the timing of the decision, almost as though he were savoring it.

title: German Music Festival to Resume After Terrorist Scare
description: BERLIN  One of Germanys biggest rock festivals was set to resume, the organizers said on Saturday, a day after the police ordered tens of thousands of fans to leave because of an unspecified terrorist threat.

title: Blue Apron Has a Good Product. Beware of the Stock.
description: Blue Apron, the meal-kit delivery company that wants to go public, serves up delicious meals and tantalizing sales growth. But look closely at the ingredients. New-customer acquisition costs are surging, customers are ordering fewer meals, and competitors abound. Like Groupon before it, Blue Apron is a case where the product is fine but the stock is best avoided.

title: Review: In David Gordons Life and Art, the Past Is the Present
description: Live Archiveography, written and staged by David Gordon, is a compelling, bewildering achievement. Astonishingly layered, its overlapping elements connect rehearsal and performance, historical film and prepared script, dance theater and personal life to become part of the history not just of Mr. Gordon but also of dance and theater. Its both new and all about recycling; its live and all about the past.

title: Robert Caro, Nearing the End of His Epic L.B.J. Bio, Eyes a Trip to Vietnam
description: An epic biography is nearing its close. Slowly but surely.

title: An Ice Cream Truck at Carnegie Hall: This Weeks 8 Best Classical Music Moments
description: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what theyve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

title: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
description: Lately it seems the made-up food holidays are multiplying. (Theres probably even a Made-Up Food Holiday holiday.)

title: Whats Keeping the Mayor From Going Green? His Gym Routine
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has a message for New Yorkers looking for a productive way to respond to President Trumps decision to remove the United States from the Paris accord on climate change: Do your part, and stop using plastic grocery bags.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Running in the Sahara
description: Have you ever daydreamed of ice cubes? The idea sounded absurd until I undertook the Marathon des Sables, a 147-mile adventure through the Saharas scorching 130-degree temperatures, towering sand dunes and steep mountain passes. When I crossed the finish line on April 14, the race had shown me the joy of suffering and how to appreciate lifes simple pleasures.

title: The Handmaids Tale Season 1, Episode 8: Profit and Pleasure
description: Behind every door in Gilead, horror breeds. Sometimes it comes in obvious forms  the gouged eyes of handmaids or the hollow gazes of women forced into prostitution. But as The Handmaids Tale nears the end of its first season, Ive become more intrigued by the horror that remains unexplored. Nothing has been granted less consideration in the series so far than Moiras perspective and the role of race in Gilead. But this weeks episode finally offers an answer to the question that has been hanging over the season: What happened to Moira?

title: Senior Congo Officials Linked to Kabila Face Sanctions for Rights Abuses
description: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo  Several senior officials in President Joseph Kabilas government were hit with sanctions this week by the European Union and the United States for planning, directing or committing serious human rights violations in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

title: Paris Agreement, C.I.A., Warriors: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Picnic Essentials
description: Enjoy your picnic with cheese and charcuterie that goes perfectly with a glass of Yellow Label.

title: Trump Golf Course Struggles in Bronx, Where Many Cant Afford to Play
description: The Bronx waited more than three decades for a landfill at the foot of the Whitestone Bridge to be transformed into a municipal golf course.

title: To Honor Canadian Natives, a Lawmaker Speaks in Mohawk
description: Cultural appropriation is a touchy topic in Canada these days, with the recent controversy in Canadian media over whether it is appropriate for nonindigenous writers to take on a native voice for artistic expression. But Marc Miller, a member of Canadas Parliament, decided he was on solid ground in giving a speech in Kanyenkha, the language of the Mohawks, in the House of Commons on Thursday.

title: Perfect Pairings
description: Elevate your afternoon with a glass of Veuve Clicquot Ros and these perfect pairings.

title: Unicef Fears Yemen Cholera Outbreak Could Hit 300,000 in Coming Weeks
description: Cholera cases in Yemen could quadruple in the next month to 300,000, the regional director of Unicef said Friday, calling the spread of the disease in the war-ravaged country incredibly dire.

title: Perfect Pairings
description: Elevate your afternoon with a glass of Veuve Clicquot Ros and these perfect pairings.

title: Picnic Essentials
description: Enjoy your picnic with cheese and charcuterie that goes perfectly with a glass of Yellow Label.

title: Economic Fallout of Climate Move? It Depends on How We Value Time
description: President Trumps decision to abandon the Paris climate accord  and his broader unwillingness to fight climate change  will have broad economic consequences.

title: Eric Broadley, Acclaimed Designer of Championship Racecars, Dies at 88
description: Eric Broadley, a onetime cabinetmaker from Britain who became an acclaimed designer of racecars whose speedy creations won the Indianapolis 500 and numerous other events, died May 28 in Cambridge, England. He was 88.

title: Husband of Kellyanne Conway Steps Back From Possible Justice Dept. Post
description: WASHINGTON  George T. Conway III, the husband of the presidential counselor Kellyanne Conway, has withdrawn himself from consideration to become the head of the Justice Departments civil division, he said in a statement on Friday, citing family considerations as he became the latest sign of personnel woes at the White House.

title: Corrections: June 3, 2017
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: What Is the Green Climate Fund and How Much Does the U.S. Actually Pay?
description: In announcing his decision to exit the Paris accord, President Trump scorned the Green Climate Fund. Does the United States contribute an outsize share?

title: W.N.B.A. Players Overseas Obligations Cramp Their Teams
description: When the Liberty traded for center Kia Vaughn in January, Coach Bill Laimbeer knew there was a caveat.

title: Mick Mulvaney on the Budget, Congressional Scorekeepers and Staying Frugal
description: Mick Mulvaney, the White House budget director, may be one of the most maligned men in Washington because he is the bearer of budget cuts. He has been accused of everything from ethnic cleansing to wanting to kill a million people. He gets fan mail with fake business cards tucked in that give his job title as a starver of hungry children and elderly.

title: Canada Today: Powerful Storytelling and Climate Politics
description: Catherine Porter, the Toronto bureau chief, and I are among a cadre of Canadians who help produce The New York Times. While some of the others are also reporters, many of the Canadians lurking within The Times are editors, which means you usually dont see their names.

title: Trump Nominates Richard Spencer as Navy Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump on Friday announced the nomination of Richard V. Spencer, an investment banker and retired Marine aviator, to be secretary of the Navy.

title: Elliot Martin, Prolific Theater Producer, Dies at 93
description: Elliot Martin, who transformed himself from a teenage radio cowboy and Broadway chorus boy into one of the pre-eminent producers of the American theater, died on May 21 at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 93.

title: Meeting the Paris Climate Goals Was Always Hard. Without the U.S., It Is Far Harder.
description: WASHINGTON  In December 2015, delegates from 195 nations announced to a roar of applause in Paris that they had finally sealed a pact aimed at keeping global temperatures from rising more than 2 degrees Celsius to avoid the worst ravages of climate change.

title: Cousin of Brussels Bombers Is Charged With Ties to Terrorist Network
description: PARIS  The police in Belgium have charged a cousin of the brothers who set off suicide bombs in Brussels in March 2016 with being part of the terrorist network that planned and carried out those attacks and the attacks in Paris in November 2015.

title: French Open Womens Draw Highlights an Age of Thirtysomethings
description: PARIS  All but gone are the days of ingnues dominating in Paris. The grandes dames look poised to remain the ruling class at Roland Garros.

title: Photographs of Marie Cosindas
description: Marie Cosindass artfully composed still lifes and portraits opened up a new world of color to a medium dominated by black-and-white images.

title: Marie Cosindas, Whose Photographs Brought Color to the Fore, Dies at 93
description: Marie Cosindas, a photographer whose painterly, artfully composed still lifes and portraits, made with Polaroid film, broke with the dominant black-and-white aesthetic of the early 1960s and opened up a new world of color, died on May 25 in Boston. She was 93.

title: Two Filipino Movie Stars Earn Meeting With an Idol (Jack Nicklaus)
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  As the two amateur golfers waited eagerly to meet Jack Nicklaus, two of their own admirers waited, star-struck themselves, to meet them.

title: Quotation of the Day: Ex-Penn State Officials Get Jail Terms in Sandusky Case
description: This is a Shakespearean tragedy; this is a fall from grace that is both unfortunate and well deserved.

title: Leaders Lament U.S. Withdrawal, but Say It Wont Stop Climate Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  World leaders vowed Friday to confront climate change in a new international coalition that no longer includes the United States government, moving quickly to reshape global environmental alliances after President Trumps decision to abandon the Paris climate accord.

title: Trauma, Taxes and Trump
description: In the middle of his speech trashing the climate accord, President Trump suddenly blurted out that his tax bill is moving along in Congress. This was something of a surprise since, A) there is no tax bill and, B) nothing is moving along in Congress.

title: Fringe Groups Revel as Protests Turn Violent
description: Kyle Chapman expected he might find a fight. And he did  with a teenage girl.

title: Six Days and 50 Years of War
description: In June 1967 Arab leaders declared their intention to annihilate the Jewish state, and the Jews decided they wouldnt sit still for it. For the crime of self-preservation, Israel remains a nation unforgiven.

title: Apple Piles On the Features, and Users Say, Enough!
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As Apple prepares to show off new features for the iPhone and other devices at its developer conference on Monday, the company is grappling with an uncomfortable issue: Many of its existing features are already too complicated for many users to figure out.

title: Jack McCloskey, Architect of Detroit Pistons Bad Boys Teams, Dies at 91
description: Jack McCloskey, whose canny decisions and steady leadership as general manager of the Detroit Pistons paved the way for their first two National Basketball Association championships, in 1989 and 90, died on Thursday in Savannah, Ga. He was 91.

title: Small Businesses Cheer New Sheriff in Town After Climate Pact Exit
description: As news that President Trump was pulling out of the Paris climate accord hit at a luncheon for small-business owners in Toledo, Ohio, on Thursday, an already happy crowd suddenly turned euphoric.

title: Weaver of Greek Mythology
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  The constructor Roland Huget is primarily a late-week constructor, playing around with a variety of open and themeless puzzle designs. In todays crossword, his seventh for The New York Times, he chooses a grid design that is new for him but, as he notes below, has been used before by other constructors.

title: De Blasio Moves to Curb Puerto Rican Militants Parade Profile
description: Oscar Lpez Rivera, the Puerto Rican nationalist at the center of a controversy over the Puerto Rican Day Parade in New York, has talked at times about how 35 years in federal prison could not break his spirit.

title: We Travel Together
description: We want fair treatment for our taxpayers. We dont want other leaders and other countries laughing at us anymore. And they wont be. They wont be. I was elected to represent the citizens of Pittsburgh, not Paris.  President Trump, June 1, 2017

title: The Problem With Jared Kushner
description: What are we supposed to make of the news that Jared Kushner, President Trumps son-in-law and senior White House adviser, met with the Russian ambassador in December to discuss establishing a back channel between the incoming Trump administration and the Kremlin, using Russian diplomatic facilities?

title: To Truly Resist Trumpism, Cities Must Look Within
description: Long before the nations attention turned to the investigation of the Trump administrations ties to Russia, the presidents discriminatory and divisive policies and rhetoric were drawing intense criticism  and cities were being lauded as leaders of the resistance against them. Some of this praise of cities is deserved. But if they are to make meaningful change, local leaders also must look inward to confront the Trumpian forces that have long existed within their own boundaries.

title: You Dont Know Tiger Woods
description: I cant remember the name of my high school biology teacher or that kind woman I had a pleasant lone date with at Corner Bistro in 2003. But I can recite the entire lineup for the 1982 St. Louis Cardinals.

title: A Conscientious Objector in a War Zone
description: Mennonites have refused to participate in war for almost 500 years. I grew up in a small Mennonite community in the Shenandoah Valley of Virginia, where Mennonites have been refusing conscription since the Civil War. Being a conscientious objector to the Vietnam War was an easy choice for me.

title: Trump Appears Unlikely to Hinder Comeys Testimony About Russia Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump does not plan to invoke executive privilege to try to prevent James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, from providing potentially damaging testimony to Congress on statements the president made about an investigation into his former national security adviser, two senior administration officials said Friday.

title: Protecting Consumers in Patent Cases
description: Patent infringement cases may seem like arcane disputes between faceless businesses. But they can have huge effects on the economy and on individual consumers. Just wait until the next time you have to buy a cartridge for your printer.

title: With Murphys Law in Effect, Yankees Cant Catch the Blue Jays
description: TORONTO  The Yankees scouting report told them exactly where Torontos Kendrys Morales would hit the ball if it were a grounder. So third baseman Chase Headley was shifted to the other side of second base, second baseman Starlin Castro moved into shallow right field and Didi Gregorius was not far from second base.

title: Manchester Bomber Met With ISIS Unit in Libya, Officials Say
description: The bomber who killed 22 people at a pop concert in Manchester, England, last month had met in Libya with members of an Islamic State unit linked to the November 2015 Paris terrorist attack, according to current and retired intelligence officials.

title: Heres How a Chinese Tech Firm Borrowed $2.1 Billion in a Hurry
description: When a Chinese tech company with global ambitions began to run short of cash last year, it sought billions of dollars from new investors. One of them was a music teacher.

title: This Time, Matt Harvey Struggles Against the Pirates
description: Not long ago, a pitching matchup of Matt Harvey versus Gerrit Cole in early June would have amounted to a summer blockbuster  a marquee attraction featuring two of baseballs finest young right arms.

title: Former Contractor Sues Dale Chihuly, Claiming He Helped Create Artwork
description: Dale Chihuly, the artist whose show of 20 glass art installations is on display spread across the 250 acres of the New York Botanical Garden, used a group of unpaid assistants for 15 years to create works that were attributed solely to him, a man claimed in a lawsuit filed on Friday in Seattle.

title: Bill Maher Apologizes for Use of Racial Slur on Real Time
description: The HBO late-night host Bill Maher apologized on Saturday for using a racial epithet during an interview with Senator Ben Sasse, Republican of Nebraska, on a live broadcast of his show on Friday night. HBO denounced the remark as completely inexcusable and tasteless, and said it would be edited out of future airings.

title: Whats on TV Saturday: A Tim Burton Trio and The Essentials
description: Tim Burton revels in freakiness in Miss Peregrines Home for Peculiar Children. And Alec Baldwin and David Letterman discuss Davids Leans Brief Encounter.

title: Fact Check: Trumps Exit From the Paris Climate Accord
description: President Trump is pulling the United States out of the Paris climate accord. The New York Times checks his claims about what the agreement really does.

title: Covfefe, the Paris Climate Accord and Other Must Read Trump News of the Past Week.
description: Worried that you missed an important political story this week? Youre not alone. Catch up on a very hectic week of news.

title: For Britains Labour Party, a Mild Defeat May Be Worst of All
description: BIRMINGHAM, England  Birmingham Northfield, a modest residential area on the southwest border of Englands second-largest city, has backed the Labour candidate for Parliament the last 25 years. But in conversations along its main shopping street, a mixture of discount stores like Pound Store Plus and a Womens Aid shop, it is not hard to detect the guilty temptation of voting Conservative as the June 8 election approaches  and the main problem bedeviling Labour.

title: Dive With a Cousteau in a Private Submarine
description: Pierre-Yves Cousteau, the youngest son of Jacques Cousteau, explores a sunken ship and artificial reef in the Bahamas. Join him in 360 degrees aboard a submersible craft.

title: Dissecting Marissa Mayers $900,000-a-Week Yahoo Paycheck
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When a withered Yahoo is absorbed by Verizon Communications in the next week or so, it will be the end of an era for one of the pioneering names of the internet age.

title: We All Have to Be Prepared to Stand Up
description: Here are the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment. Some comments were edited for length and clarity.

title: The Doctor Is In. Co-Pay? $40,000.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  When John Battelles teenage son broke his leg at a suburban soccer game, naturally the first call his parents made was to 911. The second was to Dr. Jordan Shlain, the concierge doctor here who treats Mr. Battelle and his family.

title: Are HGTVs Tarek and Christina the New Brad and Jen?
description: LOS ANGELES  Since November, a single tabloid magazine, In Touch Weekly, has devoted its cover to them in full or in part at least 14 times. In total, In Touch has done more than 90 articles on them.

title: Young Tony Nominee of Dear Evan Hansen Gets Ready for His Big Day
description: On most Wednesdays, in the roughly three-hour break between the matinee and evening performances of Dear Evan Hansen, the Tony-nominated musical playing at the Music Box Theater, the actor Mike Faist usually slips out for a walk down to the Hudson River. (Its nice to get outside and maybe get some semblance of nature, he says.) Then he grabs a light snack and a quick nap back in his tiny fourth-floor dressing room.

title: Istanbul Style by the Bosphorus
description: There is such vibrant energy in Istanbul, regardless of the political climate, the photographer Devin Yalkin said. His parents met in Nisantasi, a district on the European side. They lived across the street from each other, and when they were in their mid-20s, his father asked his mother out on a date through the window of their apartments. Ultimately they immigrated to America and Mr. Yalkin was born in Manhattan. Turkey, he said, is always a really interesting place for me to be, because I see it as a place that I could have grown up in if my parents had decided to stay.

title: The Fashion Outlaw Dapper Dan
description: The Harlem couturier Daniel Day, better known as Dapper Dan, was all over social media last week after Gucci unveiled a jacket that looked very much like one he designed nearly three decades ago for the Olympic sprinter Diane Dixon.

title: At the Summer White House, You Are Never Far From a Trump Photo
description: Under cloudy skies in fall 2002, as guests and reporters looked on, Donald J. Trump dug into the ground with a gold-painted shovel to signify the opening of  Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J.

title: India Acknowledges Three Cases of Zika Virus
description: NEW DELHI  Officials in Ahmedabad, India, saw the first of the cases in November: A 34-year-old woman who had just given birth to a healthy child came down with a fever, and tests later confirmed that she was infected with the mosquito-borne Zika virus.

title: Bared Breast Enthralls a Future Czar, and Stokes a Russian Culture War
description: MOSCOW  It is an eye-catching wardrobe malfunction that beguiles a future czar.

title: Airlines Step Up Stopover Options
description: Travelers with ambitious travel plans may find additional multicity routes at bargain rates as international airlines add free stopovers and other incentives to make the midway hub a second destination.

title: Explosions Rock Funeral in Kabul, Killing at Least 7 and Injuring Dozens
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Three explosions on Saturday rocked the funeral service of a victim of antigovernment protests in Kabul, killing at least seven people and injuring dozens after a tense and bloody week in the Afghan capital.

title: Building the Wall, Which Imagines Life After Trump, to Close
description: A political drama that sketches a dark vision of an America in recovery after the imagined impeachment of President Trump will close its New York production on Sunday  about a month before the plays producers originally intended, according to the producer, Jeffrey Richards.

title: Farhads and Mikes Week in Tech: Techies Versus Trump Again
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: The Biggest, Strangest Batteries
description: What if you need a battery? A really big one  big enough to run a city?

title: How Real Madrid Won Its Second Straight Champions League Title
description: Real Madrid resoundingly restated its case as the worlds best soccer club on Saturday, getting two goals from Cristiano Ronaldo and outclassing the Italian champion Juventus, 4-1, in the Champions League final in Cardiff, Wales.

title: He Proposed. But That Was Just the Half of It.
description: Mansi Snehal Kothari and Sushil Raja Atmakuri were married May 29 in a townhouse at 241 West 17th Street in New York, where the grooms family stayed for the wedding. Malika Atmakuri, the grooms sister, who is ordained by the American Marriage Ministries, officiated.

title: Getting Rid of Tree Roots From Next Door
description: Q. Roots from my  neighbors tree have grown under the driveway of my house in Astoria, Queens, causing the asphalt to heave, buckle and crack. Who is responsible for repairing this damage, my neighbor or me?

title: Ariel Stein and Rares Orzata: This Circus Has Two Rings
description: Ariel Melissa Stein and Rares Iulian Orzata were married June 3 at the Park Hyatt New York, in Manhattan. Justice Douglas E. McKeon of New York State Supreme Court in the Bronx, officiated.

title: The N.B.A. Finals and the LeBron James Effect
description: My first experience covering the N.B.A. finals for The New York Times remains vivid for me. It was 2014, and the San Antonio Spurs defeated the Miami Heat for the championship.

title: Video of Manila Casino Attack Shows Robbery Was Goal, Police Say
description: MANILA  Security camera footage released Saturday of the casino attack in Manila that killed 37 people shows an armed man setting fires in several rooms and stealing gambling chips but making no attempt to shoot fleeing customers and employees.

title: No, Your Phone Didnt Ring. So Why Voice Mail From a Telemarketer?
description: Frank Kemp was working on his computer when his cellphone let out the sound of Mario  from Super Mario Bros.  collecting a coin. That signaled he had a new voice mail message, yet his phone had never rung.

title: Andy Murray Gets Past Juan Martn del Potro at the French Open
description: PARIS  After the chair umpire confirmed that Juan Martn del Potros final forehand of his first set on Saturday was out, the 29th-seeded del Potro stared, still in disbelief that he had lost the opening frame of his third-round match against top-seeded Andy Murray at the French Open.

title: The View From Behind the Velvet Rope
description: Whether youre covering a political campaign, a rock concert or the launch of a new cruise ship, one of the privileges of being a reporter is being allowed behind the velvet rope  to the front of the line, onto the stage or into the limo  to interview subjects. Its not something I seek out (far from it), but as a business reporter who covered Wall Street and C.E.O.s for years, it came with the territory.

title: Obama Unwittingly Handed Trump a Weapon to Cripple the Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials knew they were on shaky ground in spending billions of dollars on health insurance subsidies without clear authority. But they did not think a long-shot court challenge by House Republicans was cause for deep concern.

title: Variety: Diagramless Crossword
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  When we last saw Brendan Emmett Quigley, he was busy building something with tools, but today hes deconstructing in more than one way. If youve never done a diagramless crossword, dont panic about the lack of grid; youre supposed to build it yourself, with hints from the numbering of the clues.

title: For David Griffin, a Cavaliers Architect, the Future Is Uncertain
description: CLEVELAND  David Griffin was on a far court, walking through offensive sets with Tyronn Lue, the coach he hired in the middle of last season. On the other side of the gym, LeBron James, the megastar he helped bring back to Ohio, stood in front of news media microphones, expounding on his Cleveland Cavaliers and the collective sharpshooters known as the Golden State Warriors, the two teams that are facing off in the N.B.A. finals for a third consecutive year.

title: Gorsuch Rejects Doubts Over Rule of Law Today
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  Justice Neil M. Gorsuch, in his first public remarks since joining the Supreme Court in April, spoke forcefully on Friday about letting judges have the last word in assessing the constitutionality of government actions.

title: For Brewers Travis Shaw, Trade Was a Blessing
description: The Boston Red Sox arrive at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday for the first of three visits, but their homegrown third baseman just left town. Travis Shaw spent four games in New York last week, helping keep his Milwaukee Brewers atop the National League Central.

title: Last Secret of 1967 War: Israels Doomsday Plan for Nuclear Display
description: On the eve of the Arab-Israeli war, 50 years ago this week, Israeli officials raced to assemble an atomic device and developed a plan to detonate it atop a mountain in the Sinai Peninsula as a warning to Egyptian and other Arab forces, according to an interview with a key organizer of the effort that will be published Monday.

title: An Ad Trump Signed Supporting Action on Climate Change
description: This ad appeared in The New York Times in December 2009, urging President Barack Obama to push a global climate change pact being negotiated in Copenhagen. Donald J. Trump and members of his family supported the ad, along with other business leaders.

title: How G.O.P. Leaders Came to View Climate Change as Fake Science
description: WASHINGTON  The campaign ad appeared during the presidential contest of 2008. Rapid-fire images of belching smokestacks and melting ice sheets were followed by a soothing narrator who praised a candidate who had stood up to President George W. Bush and sounded the alarm on global warming.

title: How the Stanley Cup Wound Up in a Canal, or Didnt
description: If you know anything about the early history of the Stanley Cup, youve probably heard this story: The Cup, hockeys most famous championship trophy, was once kicked into the Rideau Canal in Ottawa. The tale has been passed down for generations  but it probably isnt true.

title: Trump Plans to Shift Infrastructure Funding to Cities, States and Business
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump will lay out a vision this coming week for sharply curtailing the federal governments funding of the nations infrastructure and calling upon states, cities and corporations to shoulder most of the cost of rebuilding roads, bridges, railways and waterways.

title: The Single-Payer Party? Democrats Shift Left on Health Care
description: For years, Republicans savaged Democrats for supporting the Affordable Care Act, branding the law  with some rhetorical license  as a government takeover of health care.

title: What Monkeys Can Teach Us About Fairness
description: Monkeys were taught in an experiment to hand over pebbles in exchange for cucumber slices. They were happy with this deal.

title: The Tennis Mom Who Put the Blemish in Martina Navratilovas 86-1 Record
description: Kathleen Horvath peered over the railing high above the indoor courts at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center. Outside, rain was pouring down so hard that it sounded as if the New York Philharmonics percussion section were rehearsing on the roof.

title: Springtimes Not-So-Peaceable Kingdom
description: NASHVILLE  In spring, I search for nests. I part the branches of shrubs and low-limbed trees, peering into their depths for a clump of sticks and string and shredded plastic  the messy structure of a mockingbirds nest. I squat and look upward for a cardinals tidy brown bowl. I stand even with the end of my house and look from the side into the ivy climbing the bricks, searching for a tiny avian hammock tucked into the leaves by house finches. I check the fern hanging under the eaves for the vortex tunnel built by a Carolina wren. I watch at my window for blue jays flying into and out of the tree canopy, and I try to pinpoint the exact Y-crook in the branches where theyve hidden their young.

title: Written Proof That the Presidents Lobbyist Ban Is Worthless
description: We wanted to believe that President Trump was doing the right thing when the White House announced in January that executive branch officials would be banned for two years from working on policy or regulations they once were paid to influence as lobbyists and lawyers.

title: America in Retreat
description: The swiftness of President Trumps transformation of Americas global image from a proud and valued leader to something more nearly resembling a whiny bully has heads spinning at home and abroad. Mr. Trump was elected on a slogan of America First and a promise that the country would never again be bound by agreements and conventions that, in his view, compromised its sovereignty. But the policies and pronouncements that have flowed from this promise have in fact made the United States, and his presidency, the object of disbelief, alarm, even derision.

title: Trump Stomps Planet Earth
description: WASHINGTON  Weve been conditioned by Hollywood to see the president of the United States step up to the lectern to confidently tell us how he will combat the existential threat to the planet  be it aliens, asteroids, tidal waves, volcanoes, killer sharks, killer robots or a 500-billion-ton comet the size of New York City.

title: Neither Hot Nor Cold on Climate
description: LIKE a lot of conservatives who write about public policy, my views on climate change place me in the ranks of what the British writer Matt Ridley once dubbed the lukewarmers.

title: These Campus Inquisitions Must Stop
description: Racism pervades our country. Students who have roiled college campuses from coast to coast have that exactly right.

title: Innocent Until Your Mug Shot Is on the Internet
description: PORTLAND, ORE.  On a cold, rainy morning in January of last year, Matthew Medlin hopped a refrigerated freight car in downtown Portland, Ore., and headed north. Mr. Medlin is 33 and homeless, with dagger-like stripes tattooed above his eyes and four dots below them  symbols of what he described as his belief in lycanthropy, the mythical transformation of humans into wolves. He has been a habitual methamphetamine user for years. Hes schizophrenic.

title: What I Learned at Cowboy Camp
description: Lincoln, Neb.  One of the first things I did when I moved to Nebraska two years ago was find myself some cows to herd. Id moved to a state that proudly says it has more than three times as many cows as it does people in order to take a job at the University of Nebraska in Lincoln, the states capital.

title: How Interracial Love Is Saving America
description: As a descendant of slaves and slaveholders, I embody uncomfortable incongruities  just as America does. In Notes on the State of Virginia, Thomas Jefferson wrote with anguish about the risks of amalgamation, or interracial sex, to a new nation. Whites were stained when they mixed with blacks, whom he speculated were inferior in mind and form.

title: The Specialists Stranglehold on Medicine
description: Republicans are trying to cut health care spending. But hacking away at Medicaid, weakening coverage requirements and replacing Obamacares subsidies with a convoluted tax credit will not deal with the real crisis in American health care.

title: Devils, Needing an Answer, Query the Top N.H.L. Prospects
description: BUFFALO  One of the most colorful stories about an N.H.L. prospect concerned Trevor Linden and the Vancouver Canucks. In 1988, Brian Burke, the assistant general manager for the Canucks at the time, had asked Linden to come from his home in Medicine Hat, Alberta, to Vancouver for psychological testing before the draft.

title: Trumps NATO Bombast Gets Us Where Statesmanship Cant
description: Whither NATO is probably the greatest snoozer headline of the past half-century. It has been used on editorials, op-ed articles, think-tank reports  anyplace an editor wants to communicate, Ive been forced at gunpoint to publish this essay, but for Gods sake dont read it. If Donald Trump had done nothing more than to create a legitimate occasion for calling a newspaper article Whither NATO, his place in history would be assured. Small, but assured.

title: Rocketing to the Sun and Its Flaming Secrets
description: Like the countless stars that come and go, flaring and dying across the universe, the sun still holds many mysteries. That should change markedly next year when NASA launches the first satellite aimed at our own star to reveal the secrets of the suns atmosphere, the corona.

title: Choosing When and How to Die
description: To the Editor:

title: Obamas Dilemma on Troop Surge in Afghanistan Now Vexes Trump
description: WASHINGTON  A new president confronts an old war, one that bedeviled his predecessor. He is caught between seasoned military commanders, who tell him that the road to victory is to pour in more American troops, and skeptical political advisers, who argue that a major deployment is a futile exercise that will leave him politically vulnerable.

title: Nigerias Afrobeats Music Scene Is Booming, but Profits Go to Pirates
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Forcing a smile, Seyi Shay, a music star in Nigeria, stood for hours under the hot lights of a film studio to record a video. Three changes of clothes, two wigs and multiple touch-ups later, she was still at it, singing snippets of the song over and over.

title: Phil Mickelson Says Hell Skip U.S. Open to Attend Daughters Graduation
description: DUBLIN, Ohio  Phil Mickelson said on Saturday that he would withdraw from the United States Open, the only major championship he has not won, to attend what he considers a more important event  his daughter Amandas high school graduation.

title: Californias Green Rush Takes Hmong Back to Their Opium-Growing Roots
description: HAYFORK, Calif.  The red and purple opium poppies that his family grew on a mountainside half a world away were filled with an intoxicating, sticky sap that his mother traded for silver coins to feed her children and pay for their escape.

title: Fake ICE Notices Urge Washington Residents to Report Illegal Aliens
description: Richard Byrne first saw the posters in his Washington, D.C., neighborhood on Thursday morning as he walked to a commuter train station.

title: Advice to Writers
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Sometimes a theme gets you right in the feels, as the cool kids are saying these days.

title: Another Terrorist Attack Strikes the Heart of London
description: LONDON  Another night of terrorism unfolded in Britain on Saturday with two attacks that killed six civilians in the center of the capital, London police said.

title: Sara Ehrman, Outspoken Feminist With Deep Ties to Clintons, Dies at 98
description: Sara Ehrman, a fixture in liberal politics who advised President Bill Clinton on the Israeli-Arab conflict but was best known as the woman who advised a young Hillary Rodham not to move to Arkansas to marry Mr. Clinton, died Saturday in Washington. She was 98.

title: Terrorist Attacks at the Center of London
description: A van mowed down pedestrians on London Bridge, and it was reported that people were stabbed at the nearby Borough Market.

title: Attack in Manila: Terrorism or Robbery?
description: The Islamic State has claimed a Friday attack on a casino in Manila. But authorities released security-camera footage Saturday that they say shows the assailant was a thief, not a terrorist.

title: Protesters in Washington Demand Independent Russia Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The March for Truth, the latest in what has become nearly weekly demonstrations of various stripes against the Trump administration, drew a sign-waving crowd to the Washington Monument on Saturday to protest possible collusion between associates of President Trump and Russian officials in the 2016 election.

title: Real Madrid, Hard to Define, Firms Its Stamp on Champions League
description: CARDIFF, Wales  Real Madrids original Galcticos, that glittering collection of talent, could not do it. Neither could the Dream Team that Johan Cruyff built in Barcelona in the 1990s, nor its spiritual heir, constructed by Pep Guardiola and fueled by Lionel Messi, two decades later.

title: Attacks in London: What We Know and What We Dont Know
description: Visit this page for full coverage of the episode.

title: Yankees Jordan Montgomery Bends Blue Jays to His Will
description: TORONTO  When Logan Munson arrived for the start of baseball practice for his senior season at the University of South Carolina back in 2011, a tall, gangly, somewhat goofy freshman sat down in the locker room stall next to him. His name was Jordan Montgomery.

title: With Macrons Blessing, France Unveils a Sweeping Ethics Overhaul
description: PARIS  President Emmanuel Macrons justice minister Franois Bayrou presented legislation on Thursday that would drastically rein in abuses in French politics, and would amount to a vigorous reinforcement of the existing ethics apparatus.

title: How the Attacks in London Unfolded
description: Three attackers drove a white van into pedestrians on London Bridge on Saturday night before stabbing people at nearby Borough Market.

title: Corrections: June 4, 2017
description: BOOK REVIEW

title: Quotation of the Day: How G.O.P. Shifted on Climate Science
description: Most Republicans still do not regard climate change as a hoax. But the entire climate change debate has now been caught up in the broader polarization of American politics.

title: London Attacks: It Was Utter Horror
description: LONDON  It was a warm, drizzly Saturday night, and the bars at Borough Market here were packed, as usual. Tucked below an offramp of London Bridge, near the banks of the Thames, the market is a warren of narrow streets populated with trendy bars and restaurants, where some people had just finished watching the Champions League soccer final.

title: Addison Reed Enters Early, and the Mets Leave With a Victory
description: On Saturday at Citi Field against the Pittsburgh Pirates, with his team clinging to a two-run lead, Mets Manager Terry Collins called the bullpen and asked closer Addison Reed if he could throw two innings to secure a win.

title: Brandi Shipp, Paul Joseph
description: Brandi Lynne Shipp and Paul Richard Joseph were married June 3 in Brooklyn. Kim P. Kirkley, a minister of the First Nation Church, officiated at Pebble Beach in Brooklyn Bridge Park.

title: Adrienne Adams, Timothy Desmond
description: Adrienne Victoria Justine Adams and Timothy Paul Desmond were married June 3 at the home of the brides mother, in Gallatin, N.Y. George K. Wittlinger, a village justice in Ancram, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

title: Anna Lindemann, Yohei Igarashi
description: Anna Katharine Lindemann and Yohei Igarashi were married June 1 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Angel L. Lopez, a staff member in the New York City Clerks Office, officiated. On June 3, Yuka Igarashi, the grooms sister, led a wedding ceremony at the New Britain Museum of American Art in Connecticut.

title: Zoe Carter, Jared Hyatt
description: Zoe Nicole Carter and Jared Z. Hyatt were married June 3 at Calistoga Ranch, a resort in Calistoga, Calif. Marc H. Morgenstern, a friend of the couple who was appointed a deputy commissioner of civil marriages for the ceremony by San Francisco County, officiated.

title: Stephanie Akpa, Christopher Eiswerth
description: Stephanie Oluchukwu Akpa and Christopher Artley Eiswerth were married June 3 at Woodlawn Farm, an events venue in Ridge, Md. Judge Karen Nelson Moore of the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, officiated.

title: Molly Vaughan, Daniel Rothberg
description: Molly Caitlin Vaughan and Daniel Todd Rothberg were married June 3 at the Indian River Life-Saving Station Museum, a state park and museum in Rehoboth Beach, Del. Joysa Winter, a Humanist celebrant who is a rabbinic candidate with the International Institute for Secular Humanistic Judaism, led the ceremony, which incorporated Jewish and Christian elements.

title: Whitney Blake, Steven Cohen
description: Whitney Beth Blake and Steven Scott Cohen were married June 3 at the Harvard Club of New York City. Gregory Cohen, a brother of the groom who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

title: Jennifer Stencel, Evan Levine
description: Jennifer Leigh Stencel and Evan Scott Levine were married June 3 in Margaretville, N.Y. Conor M. Laver, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Margaretville Mountain Inn.

title: Omobola Babarinsa, Max Wasserman
description: Omobola Abike Babarinsa and Max Philip Wasserman are to be married on June 4 at Herrington on the Bay, an event space in North Beach, Md. The Rev. Kola Ogunlana, a Pentecostal minister, is to officiate.

title: Hannah Johnsen, Colby Wise
description: Hannah Christina Johnsen, the daughter of Cindy K. Currence and Donald P. Johnsen of Phoenix, was married June 3 to Colby James Wise, the son of George O. Wise of Sun City West, Ariz., and the late Gail Perry Wise, and the stepson of Carol Rizzi-Wise of Tempe, Ariz. The Rev. Greg Schlarb, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Mary, Star of the Sea Catholic Church in San Diego.

title: Lizzie Reifenheiser, Thomas Decarlo
description: Dorothy Elizabeth Reifenheiser, a daughter of Marianne B. Reifenheiser and Thomas V. Reifenheiser of Darien, Conn., was married June 3 to Thomas Evan Decarlo, the son of Cynthia H. Decarlo of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Lewis Decarlo. The Rev. Dale Rosenberger, the senior minister of the First Congregational Church in Darien, performed the ceremony there.

title: Mica Medoff, Daniel Low
description: Mica Silber Medoff, a daughter of Debra F. Silber and Dr. Jeffrey R. Medoff of Greensboro, N.C., is to be married June 4 to Daniel Low, a son of Carol A. Low and Joey Low of Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Eliezer Havivi is to lead the ceremony with Rabbi Mayer Moskowitz also taking part at the Farm at Old Edwards Inn and Spa in Highlands, N.C.

title: Rachel Sussman, Jesse Rose
description: Rachel Joy Sussman and Jesse Benjamin Simonds Rose were married June 3 at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in New York. Rabbi Darren Levine officiated.

title: Danielle Burke, Robert Hayward Jr.
description: Danielle Ann Burke and Dr. Robert Mead Hayward Jr. were married June 3 at Our Lady Queen of Peace Catholic Church in Boothbay Harbor, Me. The Rev. Robert Lupo, a Roman Catholic priest and a parochial vicar of the churchs All Saints Parish, performed the ceremony.

title: Samantha Diedrick, John Harris
description: Samantha Griffen Diedrick and John Gerard Harris were married June 2 in Wilmington, Del., in the chapel at the Wilmington and Brandywine Cemetery. James Harold Erskine III, a friend of the groom who was ordained by the American Marriage Ministries to preside at this event, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Marvin, Patrick Mellors
description: Dr. Elizabeth Kristen Marvin and Dr. Patrick Watson Mellors were married June 3 at the Church of the Good Shepherd in Rhinebeck, N.Y. The Rev. Douglas Crawford, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Dorothy Shapiro, Oren Lund
description: Dorothy Henderson Shapiro and Oren Matthew Lund were married June 3 at Salvage One, an event space in Chicago. Judge Joel M. Flaum of the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, in Chicago, for whom the bride served as a law clerk in 2015 and 2016, officiated.

title: Milly Turakhia, Kunal Rambhia
description: Dr. Milly Bipin Turakhia and Kunal Jethalal Rambhia were married in Baltimore on June 3. Ambrish Trivedi, a Hindu priest, led a ceremony that incorporated Jain traditions at the Baltimore Marriott Waterfront.

title: Elana Karp, Joshua Naftalis
description: Elana Rachel Karp, the daughter of Tamara R. Igel and Bruce O. Karp of New York, was married June 3 to Joshua Arditi Naftalis, a son of Donna A. Naftalis and Gary P. Naftalis also of New York. Rabbi Angela Warnick Buchdahl of Central Synagogue in New York officiated at Fairview Farm at Mecox in Bridgehampton, N.Y.

title: Shivonne Foster, Chad Jones
description: Shivonne Monae Foster and Dr. Chad Micheal Jones were married June 3 at the Carnegie Institution for Science in Washington. The Rev. Joseph D. Williamson III, the pastor of Second Baptist Church in Rock Island, Ill., officiated.

title: Laura Diss, Thomas Gradel
description: Laura Elizabeth Diss and Thomas Joseph Gradel were married June 3 at the Liberty Hotel in Boston. Jason D. Adams, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Jolie Carter, Guillermo Diaz III
description: Dr. Jolie Simone Carter, the daughter of Beverly Ann Davis Carter of Kenner, La., and Jimmy Paul Carter of Marrero, La., was married June 3 to Guillermo Diaz III, a son of Gloria Diaz of Ashland, Va., and the late Guillermo Diaz II. The Rev. Moses S. Gordon III, a Baptist minister, officiated at the Manor, an event space in West Orange, N.J.

title: Jennifer Smith, Patch Culbertson
description: Jennifer Elise Smith, a daughter of Barbara Markham Smith and David Camp Smith of Washington, was married June 3 to David Patchett Culbertson Jr., a son of Elizabeth Disch Culbertson and David P.
