description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Whats on TV Friday: Song to Song and Gypsy
description: Rooney Mara, Michael Fassbender and Ryan Gosling star in Terence Malicks Song to Song, about a musician whose dreams of success lead her into the beds of two men. And Naomi Watts plays a therapist whose walk on the wild side is way too tame for our critics enjoyment in Gypsy.

title: Yankees Prospect Dustin Fowler Is Called Up, Then Carted Off
description: CHICAGO  The instant Yankees Manager Joe Girardi saw outfielder Dustin Fowler slam into a half-wall down the first-base line on Thursday, he darted from the dugout, knowing immediately that what he would find would be serious.

title: A Meeting of Military Might in the Pacific. Also: Tony Abbott Defends Cardinal Pell (Again).
description: The Breakdown puts a selection of Australias daily news into context. Todays picks:

title: Found Poem Favorite | Doomed
description: We are honoring the top winners of our Eighth Annual Found Poem Student Contest by publishing their work from June 13 to July 3. Youll be able to read the whole collection here as we go.

title: German Parliament Approves Same-Sex Marriage
description: BERLIN  When Sarah Kermer proposed to her girlfriend in March, she knew she was in love, but she did not know when, if ever, Germany would allow them to marry.

title: How Iran Recruited Afghan Refugees to Fight Assads War
description: BAMIAN, Afghanistan  War and poverty have scattered Afghans across the globe like pieces of shrapnel. Millions of Afghans came of age in refugee camps in Pakistan and Iran or as workers in the Persian Gulf nations. The migration continues. The past few years have added a new lethal geography to the Afghan diaspora: the battlefields of President Bashar al-Assads Syria.

title: Mr. Trumps For-Profit Campaign
description: President Trump hosted a $10 million re-election fund-raiser at his own hotel in Washington on Wednesday. It may have been a first in recent presidential history: an event that lined a chief executives campaign coffers and his pockets at the same time.

title: A Sign of Hope From Mr. Tillerson
description: When the State Department rolled out its annual human rights report in March, cataloging abuses in countries around the world, Secretary of State Rex Tillerson was nowhere to be found. Unlike his recent predecessors, he didnt introduce the findings at a press briefing; in fact, there was no briefing, just an anonymous senior official taking questions by telephone.

title: Understanding Republican Cruelty
description: The basics of Republican health legislation, which havent changed much in different iterations of Trumpcare, are easy to describe: Take health insurance away from tens of millions, make it much worse and far more expensive for millions more, and use the money thus saved to cut taxes on the wealthy.

title: You Dont Need Blue Apron to Teach You to Turn On Your Oven
description: If youre a professional chef for long enough, a journalist will eventually call and say she has a great idea for a story. Her publication is going to come photograph the inside of your refrigerator. Thats when youll do what I did: Load up your fridge with groceries youll never have time to cook and pretend youre a normal person.

title: Tuners and Spinners
description: Cass Sunstein, the eminent Harvard law professor and writer, notes that some people are spinners and some people are tuners.

title: The Blood on a Tax Cut
description: Pretend you are that most improbable of combinations  a lovable billionaire. In other words, youre Warren Buffett. The politicians who worship guys like you have another treat in store: They will cut your most recent tax bill by $679,999, making you even wealthier.

title: Bonds Continue Decline as Central Banks Signal Waning Stimulus
description: A sell-off in global bonds continued on Friday, as the realization set in that the end is near for policies that have kept interest rates exceptionally low for a decade.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Carsten Hllers Playful Art
description: In his first New York exhibition since 2011, Carsten Hller offers flying mushrooms and giant dice. Step into his work in 360 degrees at the Gagosian Gallery.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Whether Mad Max Is Science Fiction or Post Apocalypse
description: Ryan writes: Is Mad Max: Fury Road a science-fiction film? One movie website contends that it belongs to another category, post apocalypse. Many zombie films fit into this genre as well. I think its a good label. What do you think?

title: A Stylish Retreat in the Heart of Prague
description: From 150 euro, about $170.

title: How to Hold a Venomous Snake
description: The snake will defecate on you, says Jim Harrison, who extracts venom from approximately 1,000 snakes every week for use in drug research and development. Learn to ignore the stink. Collecting venom requires pinching a snake firmly behind its skull until it clamps its fangs over a sterile collection vial; snakes will squirt excreta in an effort to escape. When Im done extracting the cobras, Im covered in feces and my wife wont come close to me, Harrison says.

title: Behind the Cover: 7.2.17
description: Gail Bichler, design director: For Steven Johnsons article about scientists who are trying to contact life-forms in other solar systems, we visually distilled their complicated outreach attempts to a series of simple Hellos. We wanted to evoke the feeling of old science-fiction-movie plots by showing the moment when those attempts are rewarded ... or punished.

title: The 6.18.17 Issue
description: RE: CHELSEA MANNING

title: Whose Fault Is It Anyway? Three Books on the Shifting Nature of Responsibility in American Politics
description: At some point in the last half-century, American politicians started talking about responsibility in a new way. Where responsibility once referred to the duties of the nation to its citizens, or of the citizens to the nation, or of fellow citizens to one another, it now came to mean the obligations of the individual to himself. Responsibility was personal responsibility. You might date the beginning of this shift to 1968, when Ronald Reagan, then the governor of California, announced in a speech at the Republican National Convention that it was time to stop blaming society for peoples failings and to start accepting that each individual is accountable for his actions. You might date the completion of this shift to 1993, when President Bill Clinton exhorted Americans in his first Inaugural Address to demand responsibility from all and to break the bad habit of expecting something for nothing.

title: Memory
description: This poem, taken from a collection called Madwoman, makes me ponder the relationship between memory and madness. Memory bruises and is bruised. McCallum casts memory as both wild and vulnerable, sentient and elusive. Add to that the almost wicked tone of the poem; its haunting last sentence could be followed by a madwomans cry or cackle. The rest of the book both expands and makes exact the roots of memory, madness and womanhood implied here. But you can see how beautifully the poem stands alone. Selected by Terrance Hayes

title: How an Agency of Oddballs Transformed Modern War and Modern Life
description: THE IMAGINEERS OF WAR The Untold History of DARPA, the Pentagon Agency That Changed the World By Sharon Weinberger Illustrated. 475 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $32.50.

description: AN ENGLISH GOVERNESS IN THE GREAT WAR The Secret Brussels Diary of Mary Thorp Edited by Sophie de Schaepdrijver and Tammy M. Proctor Illustrated. 280 pp. Oxford University Press. $29.95.

title: Storms Transport a Woman Into a Strangers Life and Her Own Past

title: A Newcomer to Stockholm Dining Is a Vegetarian Mecca
description: There are chefs who can fill seats based on reputation alone  lead actors whose legion admirers eagerly attend every opening. In Stockholm, that describes Mathias Dahlgren, a founder of the New Nordic Food Manifesto and a Bocuse dOr winner who has earned a cumulative four Michelin stars at three restaurants to date.

description: BEFORE DAWN ON BLUFF ROADSelected New Jersey Poems

description: BASED ON A TRUE STORY By Delphine de Vigan Translated by George Miller 378 pp. Bloomsbury. $28.

title: Michael K. Williams Is More Than Omar From The Wire
description: The Wire, HBOs five-season epic of Baltimore life, is a perennial contender for the greatest television series ever, and Michael K. Williams, in his role as the stickup man Omar Little, its most memorable actor. But on the shows first day of filming, when a prop person handed him his characters signature shotgun, Mr. Williams clutched it with a look of sheer bewilderment.

title: Helping Those Who Hoard
description: Logistics is a big part of Brendan Keanys job. As the general manager of Penn South, a sprawling co-op complex with 2,820 apartments in Chelsea, Mr. Keany is used to coordinating the schedules of his crew, contractors and residents when any repair work is required.

title: Solar Trade Case, With Trump as Arbiter, Could Upend Market
description: Millions of Americans now get their electricity, at least in part, from the solar panels that have rapidly spread throughout the country since 2010, thanks to their sharply declining cost. For customers  including homeowners, businesses and utilities  as well as for the companies that promote and install them, cheap solar panels have been a good thing.

title: A Fire-Scorched Arizona Pushes Prevention: Step 1, Clean Your Yard
description: PHOENIX  Wildfire season started early here this year.

title: Maya Weave Their Identity Into Their Soccer Team
description: XEJUYUP, Guatemala  It is a relief to take a detour and head toward a plateau, with its tropical vegetation, after driving through a steamy landscape of sugar cane fields in southern Guatemala. An hour later you arrive in Xejuyup, a town of about 4,000 people that is under the mountains or at the feet of the hill  which is what Xejuyup (pronounced shay-who-YOOP) means in the language of the Kiche Maya who live here.

title: Stephen Colbert Is Shocked That He Finds Trumps Tweets Shocking

description: A day off from work, food on the grill and a great fireworks show: These are the traditions we look forward to on the Fourth of July. But there is one tradition many of us unsuccessfully try to avoid year after year: taking awful photos of those fireworks.

description: It could be time for markets to come down from their sugar highs.

title: Young People Have Their Say About the Future of Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  When crowds calling for greater democracy occupied the streets of Hong Kong three years ago, a skinny teenager led them. When voters went to the polls last year, they elected a 23-year-old legislator, the youngest in the citys history. And when calls for Hong Kongs independence from China gained momentum, young people were again at the forefront.

title: Can You Have a Healthy Vegetarian or Vegan Pregnancy?
description: Q. Is there evidence that it is possible to have a healthy vegetarian pregnancy, without any risk to the developing fetus?

title: Blood Lines: Fishing With My Daughter
description: For a little while before the sun came up, we could imagine we were alone on the dark waves, a solitary boat beneath a full moon. The sound of the boats motor chugging along made the silence around us feel more encompassing, somehow. We had the whole of that immensity  18,000 acres of scattered islands, brackish waterways and shadow-shrouded wetlands  to ourselves. There was salt on the breeze.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Anxiety, Stomach Bugs and the Great Outdoors
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Simone Veil, Ex-Minister Who Wrote Frances Abortion Law, Dies at 89
description: Simone Veil, an Auschwitz survivor who as health minister of France championed the 1975 law that legalized abortion in that country, and who was the first woman to be chosen president of the European Parliament, died on Friday in Paris. She was 89.

title: DeVos Is Discarding College Policies That New Evidence Shows Are Effective

description: This interview with Lt. Gen. Nadja Y. West, the Army surgeon general, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: How Diksha Basu, a Novelist, Spends Her Sundays
description: The novelist Diksha Basu will write on a Sunday, but only when the mood strikes. I can only write when I feel creative and the words flow, and thats not something you can plan for, said Ms. Basu, who is working on her second novel. Her first, The Windfall, about a family who comes into a large sum of money in New Delhi, recently hit the stores and has been optioned for a possible television series. Ms. Basu, 33, who divides her time between Williamsburg, Brooklyn, and Mumbai, is married to Mikey McCleary, 48, a Bollywood music producer. The couple have a 2-month-old daughter, Sky Aria Basu-McCleary. SHIVANI VORA

title: Morning Joe Hosts and Trump Bring National Enquirer Into Their Feud
description: President Trump remained embroiled in a rumpus with two cable talk-show hosts on Friday, a surreal dispute featuring allegations of extortion, dueling tweets and low-rent insults that has little precedent in recent political history.

title: 11 Perfect Podcasts for the Fourth of July
description: The Stars and Stripes. Fireworks. Apple pie. Podcasts?

title: Dance Inspired by A Love Supreme to Open New York Live Arts Season
description: Anne Teresa De Keersmaeker, the cerebral Belgian choreographer, will return to New York this fall to open the coming season at New York Live Arts, the performing arts center in Chelsea announced on Friday.

title: With Provocative Moves, U.S. Risks Unraveling Gains With China
description: BEIJING  President Xi Jinping of China likes to call his core foreign policy strategy win-win. And President Trump likes to win.

description: Good morning.

title: Delete Hate Speech or Pay Up, Germany Tells Social Media Companies
description: BERLIN  Social media companies operating in Germany face fines of as much as $57 million if they do not delete illegal, racist or slanderous comments and posts within 24 hours under a law passed on Friday.

title: The Hurricane-Proof Beach House
description: In the summer of 2013, R. C. and Valari Staab were searching for a rental at the beach as an escape from their apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, with a few requirements in mind. It had to be close to the city, accessible by public transportation, and the public transportation had to allow you to bring pets, because we didnt have a car, said Mr. Staab, a playwright.

title: A New York Times Company Town Deep in the Ontario Wilderness
description: Instead of bringing the trees to town, The New York Times Company and the Kimberly-Clark Corporation brought a town to the trees.

title: High Drug Prices Are Bad. Cutting Them Could Be Worse.
description: Its easy to be outraged by high drug prices. Yet under current circumstances, simply slashing them could make matters worse.

title: 12 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Disappear into fiction this week with a highly engaging cast of characters, from the Italian hipsters of Class to the 70s Californians of Fly Me to the Englishwoman of How to Be Human who befriends a fox in her garden. Victor LaValles The Changeling mixes fatherhood with the supernatural, while Edward Dolnicks The Seeds of Life explains how scientists figured out the mechanics of fatherhood (and motherhood) in the first place. Reading this list on your smartphone? The iPhone just turned 10, and a new history of its creation unpacks the mysteries beneath its shiny, smooth exterior.

title: Climate of Fear Grips Journalists in Myanmar After Arrests
description: YANGON, Myanmar  This week began like many others for U Lawi Weng, a reporter in Myanmar with the online magazine The Irrawaddy: on the road with two fellow journalists in a conflict-ridden area near the eastern border with China.

title: Wimbledon Draw Reveals a Tough Path for Andy Murray
description: WIMBLEDON, England  After a disquieting lead-up to his countrys biggest tournament, the top seed and defending champion Andy Murray was dealt a tricky path by the Wimbledon draw Friday morning.

title: Jay-Z Releases His Personal and Political Album 4:44 on Tidal
description: Jay-Z is back, and he is vulnerable. But for now, his secrets are exclusive to Tidal.

title: Wimbledon: 6 Players to Watch
description: Wimbledon, the third Grand Slam tournament of the year, is set to begin on Monday. Serena Williams, the defending womens champion, is pregnant and will not play. Andy Murray, the defending mens champion, is in a midyear slump. New contenders could emerge. Here are a few players who have been in good form ahead of the tournament.

title: Ray Romano Still Fears the Funny Police
description: Ray Romano was in his office at the Warner Bros. lot in Burbank, Calif., leafing through a large blue notebook he fills with ideas he hopes to someday transform into comedy bits. Matso. Nickname till Matt loses weight, reads one. Dog life span. Shave a couple years off the tortoise, reads another. When asked to translate each cryptic note, he spins a very funny tale. Every time I have a thought, I put it in the book, he said.

title: Everything Old Is New Again, and Vice Versa
description: Ralph Guardiano, Principal and co-founder of Overabove in Essex, Conn.

title: Readers Come for the Characters but Stay for the Animals
description: BIRD BY BIRD: The novelist Mary Alice Monroe lives on the Isle of Palms, in South Carolinas Lowcountry, and her best-selling books often grapple with threats to the regions environment. The Summer Girls dealt with bottlenose dolphins, The Beach House with sea turtles; her latest, Beach House for Rent  new at No. 12 on the hardcover fiction list  continues the Beach House series and features brown pelicans along with the collapse of shorebird populations on nearby Dewees Island. Theres been a 70 percent drop in the number of North American shorebirds since the 1970s, Monroe told me in a recent phone interview on her way to Augusta, Ga., for a book event. If Im the canary in the coal mine, as Ive been called, Im singing loudly right now.

title: Retirement Savings, the Muslim Way
description: When faced with a loss in the market versus a lapse in his faith, Nabeel Hamoui, 37, a radiologist in Chicago, will invariably opt for the loss. This is because Dr. Hamoui manages his retirement portfolio in accordance with halal, or religiously sanctioned, Islamic guidelines.

title: For a Dying Father of the Bride, a Wedding Built in 24 Hours
description: Sarah Richards and Wyeth Killip were legally married on June 3 at the Renaissance Hotel in Cincinnati. More than a year earlier, they exchanged vows in an unofficial ceremony that took about 24 hours to prepare but created a moment that the father of the bride had waited a lifetime to see.

title: The Annual Home Maintenance Checklist
description: A home operates with the seasons, coming to life in the spring and hunkering down for the winter. Follow this natural arc all year long and your house will run like a well-oiled machine.

title: Filmatique: Where to Stream Foreign Movies You Cant Find Elsewhere
description: Theres a refined simplicity to the home page of Filmatique, a web-streaming service, that nicely underscores its mission. The site, which offers subscriptions for $4.95 a month and is also available on Apple TV, has a relatively small selection at the moment (about 40 films). But its browsing page, where the international titles are arrayed in short rows, with still images and short descriptions set against a plain black background, features impressive mini-collections of recent movies that have been hard to see in the United States. Many of them are barely known here, but the presentation makes them appear attractive, intriguing and maybe even (although this category isnt one that Im always sold on) important.

title: Myanmar Vows to Block U.N. Investigators From Entering
description: HONG KONG  Myanmar said on Friday that it would refuse to grant visas to three United Nations-backed experts responsible for investigating recent violence against Muslims in the predominantly Buddhist country, a move that threatens to further strain the governments relationship with the organization.

title: Happy Birthday, America. One Small Suggestion ...
description: Let us embark together on an Independence Day thought experiment. It is tendered in a spirit of amity, respect and good will by an Englishman who loves America. It may be dismissed as the ravings of a deranged colonial sentimentalist, but I am confident you will at least be polite enough to hear me out.

title: N.B.A. Free Agency: Blake Griffin and Gordon Hayward Lead This Years Class
description: It may be summer, but the N.B.A. is entering one of its key phases: the start of free agency. Teams can pick up the little pieces they need to improve, or maybe a big one to catapult them into contention.

title: A College Town Gets Ready for Its Moment Under No Sun
description: CARBONDALE, Ill.  During football season, a maroon mob gathers in Saluki Stadium as thousands of Southern Illinois University fans come to cheer their hometown heroes. On Aug. 21, nearly three weeks before the first game, crowds will again pack the stadium. But all eyes will be on the sky, not the field.

title: A Doctor Is Killed, and Many Feel Our Headline Doesnt Do Her Justice
description: The Reader Center is a newsroom initiative that is helping The Times build deeper ties with our audience.

title: What Happens Just Before Show Time at the Met Opera, in 12 Rooms Youll Never See
description: We walked through the Met with a steadicam on the busiest week of the year. (Featuring: Misty Copeland, Toscaninis head, wigs, harps and a snow yak.)

title: Austrias Top Court Upholds Seizing of Hitlers Birthplace
description: BERLIN  The Austrian Constitutional Court said on Friday that the government had acted legally when it seized the apartment complex in which Hitler was born, the latest and probably the last chapter in the long battle for ownership of the Nazi dictators birthplace.

title: Canadas Hidden History, My Mother and Me
description: I was 2 weeks old when I was taken from my mother. After a late night of drinking, she got into a fight, the police were called and, I am told, they found me swaddled and alone on a motel bed in La Ronge, Saskatchewan. She was in her late 20s. It wasnt until I reached my late 20s that I understood the path that led my mother to that moment.

title: Like His Father, Donald Trump Jr. Uses Twitter to Target the Media
description: Donald Trump Jr., the presidents eldest son, doesnt always take after his father. He finds little joy in wandering gilded rooms. He would rather go hunting than play a round of golf. He has little interest in becoming a politician.

title: Sothebys Makes the Best of a Thinner Summer Season
description: LONDON  The big contemporary art auctions in London at the end of June and the beginning of July have traditionally been the finale to a hectic few months in the international art market. But how significant are they now that Christies is no longer holding summer contemporary sales in the city, and that more multimillion-dollar business is being done at the Art Basel fair in Switzerland in mid-June? Have wealthy collectors minds already left for the Hamptons or Tuscany? These questions hovered in the air before Wednesday nights contemporary art auction at Sothebys.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: For Manhattan Fare Beaters, One-Way Ticket to Court May Be Over
description: For two decades, arresting people who jumped subway turnstiles has been a crucial tool of New York City policing. Fare beating was one of the petty offenses enforced aggressively on the theory that doing so would curb more serious crimes.

title: What Is FilmStruck, and Should I Subscribe?
description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: What Divided the Cosby Jurors? Words, for One Thing
description: One hurdle prosecutors had to clear to secure a conviction of Bill Cosby was obvious from the start of his sexual assault trial. The credibility of the complainant, Andrea Constand, who had continued contact with him after the night she says she was drugged and assaulted, would be critical.

title: Puerto Ricos Creditors
description: To the Editor:

title: How Much for This Jeroboam? For This Famous Chef? Food Festivals Lure the Wealthy

description: To defer, or not to defer?

title: Eggplant Favorites, Rooted in Sicily
description: Its hard to imagine Sicilian cooking without eggplant. You find it in every market, in every restaurant and certainly in every home kitchen. Having recently visited Sicily, I remember each eggplant binge fondly  and there were many.

title: Can K-pop Conquer America?
description: The Popcast is hosted by Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times. It covers the latest in pop music criticism, trends and news.

title: Review: In Ink, a Media Mogul Is Born  Rupert Murdoch
description: LONDON  The soft-spoken yet intense man commanding center stage has a familiar name, but few are likely to have thought of him in this guise. Thats because the Rupert Murdoch portrayed in James Grahams fiendishly entertaining, if structurally unbalanced, new play, Ink, is the Australian-born mogul as a young man who, in 1969, was just making inroads into the British press; he hadnt yet taken his show on the global road.

title: Inside the Renovated Htel de Crillon
description: A Parisian hotel with a History gets a stylish makeover.

title: From N.B.A. Bench Player to Cult Hero in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL

title: S.E.C. Lets All Firms Keep Parts of I.P.O. Filings Secret
description: In an attempt to revitalize the public capital markets, the nations top regulator of stocks is turning to stealth mode.

title: An Artist at Home on the Fault Lines
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  Analia Sabans studio here, which she took over from John Baldessari eight years ago, is still packed with remnants from the early, heady, low-rent days when conceptual art started in Los Angeles. She points out boxes of correspondence and records left behind by Mr. Baldessari, a pioneer of the movement.

title: Chicago Police and Federal Agents to Team Up on Gun Violence
description: CHICAGO  As a candidate, Donald J. Trump frequently mentioned the shootings that claim hundreds of lives here each year. As a new president, he threatened on Twitter to send in the Feds! if the local authorities did not stop the carnage. Five months later, Mr. Trump had another message about the city, as officials here announced a program that deploys more federal agents to address the citys gun crime.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: This unfailingly vibrant outdoor music series will enter its 20th season on Saturday at 3 p.m., with performances and D.J. sets by Jackmaster of Glasgow, DJ EZ of London, VHVL of Harlem and others. Visitors to Warm Up, which continues Saturdays through Sept. 2 with a different slate of performers every week, will find the designs of the architecture firm Jenny Sabin Studio stretched tight across the courtyard of MoMA PS1, the Museum of Modern Art outpost in Long Island City, Queens. Lumen was selected as the winner of this years Young Architects Program, a competition seeking original designs for temporary installations that afford water, seating and shade (however perforated). LOUIS LUCERO II

title: Deciding When to Use Your Own Router
description: Q. If my broadband provider gives me one of those modem-router combination boxes for my service, do I have to use it or can I use my own? What are the pros and cons?

title: In Hong Kong, a Bureau Evolves With Its City
description: For the past two decades, The New York Times had its Hong Kong bureau in a beautiful apartment halfway up the slopes of Victoria Peak, with a view of the harbor that gradually narrowed as more tall buildings were built farther down the hill.

title: Canadas Comedy, the Voice of a Polite Nation, Rises in the Trump Era
description: TORONTO  Canadians have a lot to process these days. Immigration is changing society. The Trump presidency is altering Canadas place in the world and filling its airwaves with the neighbors issues.

title: Emmanuel Macron Raises the Presidential Portrait Stakes
description: For anyone who has ever doubted the extent to which politicians consider their image, the official portrait of President Emmanuel Macron of France that was released on Thursday should put any lingering questions permanently to rest.

title: Use Berries in Abundance
description: My relationship with berries follows the same arc as so many relationships: ignorance, discovery, infatuation, growth, complacency and, then, happy coexistence.

title: Daily Report: In Paris, They Do Start-Ups With Style
description: In Silicon Valley, people famously work long hours. Do what it takes. Perfect that gadget or widget. Help your wealthy venture capital backer raise the money necessary to buy that sweet summer villa on Capri.

title: 3 Officials Resign Amid Outcry Over Grenfell Tower Fire
description: LONDON  Three officials involved with Grenfell Tower, the apartment building where at least 80 people died on June 14, announced their resignations on Friday, as the political fallout over Britains deadliest fire in decades intensified.

title: Review: Mark Morris and Lou Harrison, a Large-Spirited Partnership
description: LENOX, Mass.  Though born almost 40 years apart, the composer Lou Harrison and the choreographer Mark Morris, both from the West Coast, became one of the great artistic partnerships. Harrison, an artist whose musical style often turned to the Pacific Rim rather than to Europe or the eastern United States, died in 2003; this year is his centenary. I think of him as this nations equivalent to the Czech composer Leos Janacek (1854-1928). Both were imaginative modernists with marvelous veins of melodic lyricism and strong appetites for folk material, thrilling sonorities and drivingly percussive rhythms.

title: New Contest to Bolster London as a Cultural Hot Spot
description: LONDON  Londons mayor, Sadiq Khan, who would like to bolster the citys reputation as a cultural powerhouse, announced a new initiative Friday designed to get the creative juices flowing in its 32 boroughs.

title: A Late Debut in the Tour de France: The Scars Tell Why
description: When the Tour de France begins on Saturday, with riders zipping along the banks of the Rhine, their heads down and their legs churning, youll have to pay close attention to spot the Americans in the field of nearly 200. Very close.

title: De Blasio and Cuomo Establish Peace, for Now
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio has tried a full-frontal attack. He has tried sitting down for a private dinner in Midtown Manhattan to create a dtente. He has tried building coalitions of like-minded politicians and supporters to exert outside pressure.

title: A Handmaids Tale of Protest
description: Silent, heads bowed, the activists in crimson robes and white bonnets have been appearing at demonstrations against gender discrimination and the infringement of reproductive and civil rights.

title: Ticktock as Taskmaster: A Show About Metronomes and Musical Time
description: BASEL, Switzerland  When you enter the Museum of Music here, you are first met with a sequence of tests. A finger clip takes your pulse. A treadmill measures your pace. Next up is a snare drum station, where you don headphones and tap in time to a regular beat, then try to maintain it after the auditory cues fell silent. An electronic display notes rhythmic accuracy in percentages.

title: How SeaWorld Disregards Its Shareholders
description: SeaWorld Entertainment, the theme park company, stood accused in a 2013 documentary of abusing the captive killer whales that performed at its venues, charges it denied. But now its becoming known for disregarding another constituency: its shareholders.

title: Postcard From Australia: Souvenirs, Slang and Stereotypes
description: BYRON BAY, Australia  I wandered into a gift shop in this picturesque town, and it was hard to miss the rugby balls and jerseys, beach towels and flags. I browsed a rack with hundreds of postcards touting the same Aussie flair, including two that parodied the countrys slang  Hes blotto, for instance, means that someone is too drunk to stand.

title: Red, Wet and Bitter  but Not Campari or Aperol
description: Its easy to see red when visiting Dante, a cocktail bar and restaurant in Greenwich Village: So many of the bottles on display glow ruby and crimson and scarlet. These bittersweet liqueurs, many from Italy but some not, are called bitters or aperitivos and are used in many of the light-bodied drinks that Dante makes its specialty.

title: The Bold Type, a Modern Gloss on Sex and the Single Girl
description: BURBANK, Calif.  To tweet or not to tweet? Thats one pressing question for the editors at Scarlet magazine, the Cosmopolitan stand-in at the heart of the new series The Bold Type.

title: Trump Warms to Old Idea: Kill Health Law Now, and Replace It Later
description: WASHINGTON  With Senate Republicans already bogged down over how to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, President Trump on Friday tossed in a new complication with an old idea: The Senate could repeal the health law now, then replace it later.

title: What Cookies and Meth Have in Common
description: As a psychiatrist, I have yet to meet a patient who enjoys being addicted to drugs or compulsively overeating.

title: The Muslim Prom Queen and Me
description: THIS summer, Ive traded in my usual hijab for a turban. The biggest consequence of this is not physical. Its a matter of perception: I am no longer immediately identified as Muslim. I could just be protecting my hair from the outside elements or protecting the outside elements from my uncooperative hair. I could just be from some obscure African country  and coincidentally, I am. Or I could just be a little too obsessed with Zadie Smith.

title: After Killing Currency, Modi Takes a Leap With Indias Biggest-Ever Tax Overhaul
description: MUMBAI, India  For the second time in less than a year, the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi is putting India through a revolution in the way the country does business.

title: Wall Street Journal Said to Reduce Print Operations Outside U.S.
description: The Wall Street Journal is scaling back its print operations in Europe and Asia, two people familiar with the plans said on Friday, part of efforts by the news organization to cut costs and focus on its digital offerings.

title: French Puzzle Over Macron as Their New President Gathers Up Power
description: PARIS  Is he Machiavelli, Bonaparte or de Gaulle? Emmanuel Macron wrote a thesis about the first, is often compared to the second and frequently cites the third.

title: From Chelsea Mannings DNA Springs an Art Show
description: It started with hair clippings and a Q-tip of saliva, mailed from a military prison in Fort Leavenworth, Kansas. Now its a show at the Fridman Gallery that opens on Aug. 2.

title: Claims Over Shellfish Fuel a Battle in the Bay
description: OYSTER BAY, N.Y.  The bounteous shellfish here in this hamlet on the North Shore of Long Island are so iconic, they were extolled by Cole Porter in his song Lets Do It, with its line about oysters down in Oyster Bay doing it.

title: Doctor Opens Fire at Bronx Hospital, Killing a Doctor and Wounding 6
description: A disgruntled doctor armed with an AR-15 rifle and wearing a lab coat went on a rampage on Friday in the Bronx hospital where he had worked, killing a doctor and wounding six other people  five of them seriously  before setting himself on fire and shooting himself in the head, the authorities said.

title: Venus Williams Faces Wrongful-Death Suit in Crash
description: The daughter of a man killed in a car crash involving the tennis star Venus Williams has filed a wrongful-death lawsuit against her.

title: Clouds Are Forming Over the Bond Market
description: The bond market is flashing warning signals that bad times may be ahead for the stock market and the economy.

title: Suicide Bombers Attack Lebanese Soldiers Near Syria Border
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Five suicide bombers attacked Lebanese soldiers searching for militants in refugee settlements near the border with Syria on Friday, the army said, and the explosions killed a girl and wounded a number of soldiers.

title: Kylie and Kendall Jenner, Accused of Exploitation, Apologize for T-Shirts
description: A T-shirt bearing an image of the hip-hop artist Tupac Shakur was briefly on sale this week. It featured his photograph in black and white, with two bright yellow letters, kk, splashed across his torso.

title: Health Care Is Complicated. Trumps Pitch? Not So Much.
description: If your only source of information were President Trump, this is what you would know about the American Health Care Act, the Republican legislation to repeal and replace Obamacare.

title: For Two San Francisco Transplants, an Easy Transition
description: While its common to hear about people who made moving to New York a major life objective, many transplants end up in the city more by happenstance than intention  here thanks to a job, a graduate program or a partner, rather than a burning desire to be a New Yorker.

description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

description: After the Phoenix Mercury finished the 2016 season at 16-18, their general manager, Jim Pitman, knew the team needed a change.

description: We walked through the Met with a steadicam on the busiest week of the year. (Featuring: Misty Copeland, Toscaninis head, wigs, harps and a snow yak.)

title: Plan on Growing Old? Then the Medicaid Debate Affects You
description: These are the stories we tell ourselves: I will never be poor. I will never be disabled. My child will develop normally. They stand a decent chance of being true, even.

title: Trump Backers Furious That Senator Stood Against Health Care Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Dean Hellers biting denunciation of the Republican health care bill last week infuriated the White House and helped unravel his partys attempt to repeal the Affordable Care Act days before a vote was expected in the Senate.

title: Review: America in Color Refreshes 20th-Century History
description: You might not learn anything new about 20th-century American history from America in Color, a docu-series on the Smithsonian Channel, but the program might make you feel differently about that history. A few splashes of color will do that.

description: Hats off, gentleman  a genius!

description: The penthouse at the pinnacle of 56 Leonard, the distinctive Jenga-like glass skyscraper in the heart of TriBeCa, has finally sold.

description: Watching is The New York Timess TV and film recommendation newsletter and website.

title: Eloquent Understatement: This Weeks 8 Best Classical Moments
description: In addition to reviews, features and news during the week, our critics and reporters collect the best of what theyve heard: notes that sent shivers down their spines, memorable voices, quotations that cut to the heart of the story.

title: New Condo Complaints Heat Up
description: Look back to the end of the last housing cycle, and the downturn was marked by a flurry of complaints from condo owners and their boards against developers, claiming defects in new or renovated buildings. Roofs and pipes leaked, balconies crumbled and facades cracked. The ensuing lawsuits dragged on for years, as homeowners struggled to recoup their losses.

title: Gavin Long and His Hatred of the Police
description: The suicide note written by Gavin Long, who was fatally shot by police in Baton Rouge, La., after he killed three police officers and a deputy sheriff in July 2016.

title: Gunman Called Police Shootings a Necessary Evil in a Suicide Note
description: The man who opened fire last summer on law enforcement officers in Baton Rouge, La., killing two policemen and a deputy sheriff, carried out his ambush to create substantial change within Americas police force and judicial system, according to a suicide note that investigators released on Friday.

title: In The Beguiled, Pretty Confections Whipped Up to Seduce
description: No ladies swoon in The Beguiled, Sofia Coppolas toxic thriller set in the South during the waning months of the Civil War. The movies mostly female cast members  led by Nicole Kidman as Miss Martha, headmistress of a girls boarding school, and Kirsten Dunst as the maidenly Edwina teaching French to her overheated charges  are far too busy vying for the affections of the lone man in their midst.

title: Sketching Performer Auditions for the M.T.A.
description: Once a year,the Metropolitan Transportation Authority holds auditions for musicians to perform in subway and commuter train stations, and for thepast couple of years,Joan Chiverton, an illustrator and music lover, has sketched the hopefuls. The auditions, which take place in Grand Central Terminal, have a festive atmosphere, starting with the master of ceremonies,Robert Holman, the poet and indefatigable poetry evangelist, who wears a referees striped shirt and blows a whistle on musicians who exceed their five-minute time limit.

title: Watch Bill Murray Talk About Singing Badly (While Singing Well)
description: It takes real skill to sing badly, according to Bill Murray. Youve got to be pretty good to be a bad singer, said Mr. Murray, who for years crooned off-key as the quintessential lounge singer on Saturday Night Live. I was proud of that work, he said. My bad singing is right up there. It wasnt easy.

title: Open Thread: This Week in Style News
description: Each week, the Open Thread newsletter will offer a look from across The New York Times at the forces that shape the dress codes we share, with Vanessa Friedman as your personal shopper. The latest newsletter appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Women in Tech Speak Frankly on Culture of Harassment
description: Their stories came out slowly, even hesitantly, at first. Then in a rush.

title: At the Prado, Love That Now Dares to Shout Its Name
description: MADRID  The term homosexuality was first coined at the end of the 19th century, by which time the Prado Museum here had almost finished assembling Spains largest art collection.

title: Colleagues in Blue Hold Their Collective Breath for Injured Officer
description: It has been a month since Officer Dalsh Veve of the New York City police was grievously injured on June 3 while investigating reports of gunfire on a Brooklyn street that turned out to be fireworks outside a 2-year-old boys birthday party. Officer Veve was slung off a fleeing car and rushed by colleagues to a hospital with catastrophic head trauma.

description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Review: The House Is a Comedy Built on Despair
description: The House, a new comedy starring Will Ferrell and Amy Poehler, has arrived in theaters without advance screenings for critics. I know better than to take it personally when this kind of thing happens, but I do often wonder why it does happen. Usually the studio (Warner Bros. in this case) thinks it has a turkey on its hands, but sometimes it doesnt know quite what it has, and sneaks an interesting movie into theaters more or less by mistake. That seems to have been the case this time.

title: Moon Jae-in, Mika Brzezinski, Jay-Z: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: De Blasio, in Reversal, Says New York Will Pay $2 Million for His Lawyers
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio said on Friday that he would let the city cover most of his legal bills deriving from federal and state investigations into his activities  reversing an earlier, bottom-line pledge that no taxpayer money would be used to pay his lawyers.

title: Your Fourth of July Quiz
description: Lets see how much attention youve been paying to current presidential events.

title: Canada Letter: Its July 1. Lets Party. Wait, Why Today?
description: On Saturday, Canada celebrates the 150th anniversary of  something. Just exactly what and why is open to interpretation. Its not exactly a birthday, no one knows why its July 1 and a good many people in Canada dont have much to celebrate.

title: Conquering the Times of London Cryptic Crossword
description: SPECIAL POST  As part of the 20th anniversary of the publication of the Harry Potter novels by author J. K. Rowling, cryptic crossword constructor Brian Greer made two puzzles for June 26, 2017: a cryptic for The Times of London and his debut American-style crossword in The New York Times. As far as we know, this was the first time that an individual constructor made two similarly-themed crosswords of such different styles that ran on the same day.

title: The Land of Salt and Fire
description: Visit the hottest place on Earth, where camel caravans move salt across the vast plains, and active geothermal zones turn into a landscape of psychedelic colors.

title: The Land of Salt and Fire
description: A virtual reality film that transports you to the hottest place on Earth, where camel caravans move salt across the vast plains, and active geothermal zones turn into a landscape of psychedelic colors.

title: A Way to Own Your Social-Media Data
description: The European Union imposed a 2.4 billion euro ($2.7 billion) fine on Google last Tuesday for manipulating its search engine results to favor its own comparison shopping service. It is just the latest institution to recognize the increasing monopolization of the technology industry.

title: What to Cook, Watch, Listen To and More This Weekend
description: Happy Fourth of July weekend! Fire up the grill, eat good food, hit the beach with friends and family, and take terrible fireworks photos.
